A yellow dressinggown, ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him on the mild morning air.	8.640163431939737
He held the bowl aloft and intoned: —_Introibo ad altare Dei_.	9.668278306545771
Halted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely: —Come up, Kinch! Come up, you fearful jesuit! Solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest.	13.913557548572578
He faced about and blessed gravely thrice the tower, the surrounding land and the awaking mountains.	9.878385032520786
Then, catching sight of Stephen Dedalus, he bent towards him and made rapid crosses in the air, gurgling in his throat and shaking his head.	11.323677340834996
Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking gurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light untonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak.	10.750752973934674
Buck Mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the bowl smartly.	15.382961754139455
—Back to barracks! he said sternly.	13.677654803889983
He added in a preacher’s tone: —For this, O dearly beloved, is the genuine Christine: body and soul and blood and ouns.	11.829967934803745
Slow music, please.	8.69109789785807
Shut your eyes, gents.	13.40875204467001
One moment.	7.0411249363666295
A little trouble about those white corpuscles.	11.331459373889949
Silence, all.	5.745451265051952
He peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused awhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there with gold points.	10.05984326813674
Chrysostomos.	32.172570290454246
Two strong shrill whistles answered through the calm.	10.289582649947373
—Thanks, old chap, he cried briskly.	13.179111301570018
That will do nicely.	13.31861775157894
Switch off the current, will you?	7.993734344295773
He skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering about his legs the loose folds of his gown.	10.393424846993357
The plump shadowed face and sullen oval jowl recalled a prelate, patron of arts in the middle ages.	7.161250958357593
A pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips.	6.862742189850061
—The mockery of it! he said gaily.	17.078543841221954
Your absurd name, an ancient Greek! He pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet, laughing to himself.	9.930072016359711
Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as he propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and lathered cheeks and neck.	10.312540315203282
Buck Mulligan’s gay voice went on.	9.778549819949427
—My name is absurd too: Malachi Mulligan, two dactyls.	15.148338897124466
But it has a Hellenic ring, hasn’t it?	8.357475969441774
Tripping and sunny like the buck himself.	8.465542560682039
We must go to Athens.	17.360569477337084
Will you come if I can get the aunt to fork out twenty quid?	10.924204542185223
He laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried: —Will he come?	13.087072556519756
The jejune jesuit! Ceasing, he began to shave with care.	9.336996961451465
—Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly.	14.026337667548084
—Yes, my love?	21.02878455360687
—How long is Haines going to stay in this tower?	15.750573726309476
Buck Mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder.	11.949660066590146
—God, isn’t he dreadful?	14.415377303034193
he said frankly.	34.10226434485354
A ponderous Saxon.	10.029007476173597
He thinks you’re not a gentleman.	10.73189281112509
God, these bloody English! Bursting with money and indigestion.	10.077670672245528
Because he comes from Oxford.	16.500474074660357
You know, Dedalus, you have the real Oxford manner.	13.805916167584126
He can’t make you out.	10.070543760781726
O, my name for you is the best: Kinch, the knife-blade.	17.816260692705022
He shaved warily over his chin.	10.643889793573718
—He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said.	8.456795854603845
Where is his guncase?	21.203508950831377
—A woful lunatic! Mulligan said.	5.859357630287127
Were you in a funk?	24.59076086866947
—I was, Stephen said with energy and growing fear.	9.809760149944527
Out here in the dark with a man I don’t know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a black panther.	10.55684633721382
You saved men from drowning.	8.735648925468418
I’m not a hero, however.	11.812544292976042
If he stays on here I am off.	9.503129564000867
Buck Mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade.	23.36990273703006
He hopped down from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily.	9.413693260899024
—Scutter! he cried thickly.	12.231215773912831
He came over to the gunrest and, thrusting a hand into Stephen’s upper pocket, said: —Lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor.	12.554149518756429
Stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a dirty crumpled handkerchief.	11.82973718765008
Buck Mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly.	11.888822185125882
Then, gazing over the handkerchief, he said: —The bard’s noserag! A new art colour for our Irish poets: snotgreen.	13.708766401175147
You can almost taste it, can’t you?	10.546326358121314
He mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair oakpale hair stirring slightly.	11.49903911172876
—God! he said quietly.	14.69233300689106
Isn’t the sea what Algy calls it: a great sweet mother?	12.304822491245499
The snotgreen sea.	6.01668524543319
The scrotumtightening sea.	5.775309789998608
_Epi oinopa ponton_.	12.318195011510658
Ah, Dedalus, the Greeks! I must teach you.	15.134823500417612
_Thalatta! Thalatta!_ She is our great sweet mother.	9.707794069455698
Come and look.	9.531914907752101
Stephen stood up and went over to the parapet.	14.655012526528017
Leaning on it he looked down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of Kingstown.	11.567532288770538
—Our mighty mother! Buck Mulligan said.	5.997903483326249
He turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen’s face.	10.338971622247078
—The aunt thinks you killed your mother, he said.	6.892632943411042
That’s why she won’t let me have anything to do with you.	10.930938783433957
—Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily.	15.550270254503523
—You could have knelt down, damn it, Kinch, when your dying mother asked you, Buck Mulligan said.	10.298434633641596
I’m hyperborean as much as you.	9.063116655466429
But to think of your mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and pray for her.	10.419397119191917
And you refused.	15.787419753610662
There is something sinister in you....	4.057047564401393
He broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek.	7.177379204128327
A tolerant smile curled his lips.	5.17181259337643
—But a lovely mummer! he murmured to himself.	9.392114410147611
Kinch, the loveliest mummer of them all! He shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously.	14.014679862837832
Stephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve.	12.431748659006054
Pain, that was not yet the pain of love, fretted his heart.	9.038876856662373
Silently, in a dream she had come to him after her death, her wasted body within its loose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath, that had bent upon him, mute, reproachful, a faint odour of wetted ashes.	10.35718483402654
Across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a great sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him.	9.533460797873266
The ring of bay and skyline held a dull green mass of liquid.	8.109790440830439
A bowl of white china had stood beside her deathbed holding the green sluggish bile which she had torn up from her rotting liver by fits of loud groaning vomiting.	8.921651477555745
Buck Mulligan wiped again his razorblade.	14.966692757054698
I must give you a shirt and a few noserags.	21.105986437003175
How are the secondhand breeks?	14.880259024655668
—They fit well enough, Stephen answered.	10.090191892707349
—The mockery of it, he said contentedly.	16.621537420232283
Secondleg they should be.	7.215947577140618
God knows what poxy bowsy left them off.	6.56182725846441
I have a lovely pair with a hair stripe, grey.	12.949548468520424
You’ll look spiffing in them.	8.335235117889326
I’m not joking, Kinch.	10.05311981549303
You look damn well when you’re dressed.	15.03861706293679
—Thanks, Stephen said.	4.54079568456556
I can’t wear them if they are grey.	15.666809455341541
—He can’t wear them, Buck Mulligan told his face in the mirror.	15.813254734070831
Etiquette is etiquette.	10.245125659879218
He kills his mother but he can’t wear grey trousers.	11.77366270332314
He folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the smooth skin.	7.1017793929688695
Stephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its smokeblue mobile eyes.	10.969970898380065
—That fellow I was with in the Ship last night, said Buck Mulligan, says you have g.	15.554315896019869
p.	17.705247751504768
i.	32.172570290454246
He’s up in Dottyville with Connolly Norman.	11.165706941358797
General paralysis of the insane! He swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings abroad in sunlight now radiant on the sea.	9.076346025983462
His curling shaven lips laughed and the edges of his white glittering teeth.	10.01457519171509
Laughter seized all his strong wellknit trunk.	9.354743228223526
—Look at yourself, he said, you dreadful bard! Stephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him, cleft by a crooked crack.	13.29216552989614
Hair on end.	7.2643311668317905
As he and others see me.	7.666341760324191
Who chose this face for me?	7.9273009311476965
It asks me too.	5.209088514123807
—I pinched it out of the skivvy’s room, Buck Mulligan said.	10.991607985196534
It does her all right.	6.829632308859967
The aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for Malachi.	7.010414032689486
Lead him not into temptation.	11.526509241577275
And her name is Ursula.	19.607147993364862
Laughing again, he brought the mirror away from Stephen’s peering eyes.	13.625629577773534
—The rage of Caliban at not seeing his face in a mirror, he said.	7.56786399578125
If Wilde were only alive to see you! Drawing back and pointing, Stephen said with bitterness: —It is a symbol of Irish art.	11.130151754685567
The cracked lookingglass of a servant.	11.041539557592843
Buck Mulligan suddenly linked his arm in Stephen’s and walked with him round the tower, his razor and mirror clacking in the pocket where he had thrust them.	11.813715698021218
—It’s not fair to tease you like that, Kinch, is it?	10.192906198045144
he said kindly.	23.805974004768796
God knows you have more spirit than any of them.	8.537668503057228
Parried again.	5.364875352896063
He fears the lancet of my art as I fear that of his.	8.611429883727928
The cold steel pen.	13.232776179435904
—Cracked lookingglass of a servant! Tell that to the oxy chap downstairs and touch him for a guinea.	10.996481391456143
He’s stinking with money and thinks you’re not a gentleman.	12.619465437233014
His old fellow made his tin by selling jalap to Zulus or some bloody swindle or other.	7.062386347148027
God, Kinch, if you and I could only work together we might do something for the island.	15.791544904538126
Hellenise it.	3.903055991727408
Cranly’s arm.	14.097761501673679
His arm.	8.262366375861127
—And to think of your having to beg from these swine.	11.845696142579616
I’m the only one that knows what you are.	12.506376774057513
Why don’t you trust me more?	13.07646057552036
What have you up your nose against me?	10.590080687174888
Is it Haines?	24.21208679475912
If he makes any noise here I’ll bring down Seymour and we’ll give him a ragging worse than they gave Clive Kempthorpe.	10.747901912725188
Young shouts of moneyed voices in Clive Kempthorpe’s rooms.	8.839274821590706
Palefaces: they hold their ribs with laughter, one clasping another.	8.693699442590168
O, I shall expire! Break the news to her gently, Aubrey! I shall die! With slit ribbons of his shirt whipping the air he hops and hobbles round the table, with trousers down at heels, chased by Ades of Magdalen with the tailor’s shears.	11.24736909489756
A scared calf’s face gilded with marmalade.	11.093660771502687
I don’t want to be debagged! Don’t you play the giddy ox with me! Shouts from the open window startling evening in the quadrangle.	12.577749698559638
A deaf gardener, aproned, masked with Matthew Arnold’s face, pushes his mower on the sombre lawn watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms.	6.8026465925914055
To ourselves...	2.4951008647228776
new paganism...	2.3608030459348393
omphalos.	32.172570290454246
—Let him stay, Stephen said.	5.057005848982789
There’s nothing wrong with him except at night.	11.298613927268086
Buck Mulligan asked impatiently.	16.255406992669137
Cough it up.	5.093496639453925
I’m quite frank with you.	7.601638765949968
What have you against me now?	12.324765112902789
They halted, looking towards the blunt cape of Bray Head that lay on the water like the snout of a sleeping whale.	12.214634394930497
Stephen freed his arm quietly.	9.383689111865634
—Do you wish me to tell you?	14.316975371196941
he asked.	5.571194519539272
—Yes, what is it?	9.184307366227818
Buck Mulligan answered.	11.309981438673294
He looked in Stephen’s face as he spoke.	13.642222759375182
A light wind passed his brow, fanning softly his fair uncombed hair and stirring silver points of anxiety in his eyes.	6.088350126922067
Stephen, depressed by his own voice, said: —Do you remember the first day I went to your house after my mother’s death?	18.12943767264635
Buck Mulligan frowned quickly and said: —What?	13.287330196066325
Where?	14.052664453048125
I can’t remember anything.	13.32456790584569
I remember only ideas and sensations.	11.020392169658244
Why?	12.512270304170855
What happened in the name of God?	14.950948986437654
—You were making tea, Stephen said, and went across the landing to get more hot water.	12.12059028642567
Your mother and some visitor came out of the drawingroom.	14.408584209379741
She asked you who was in your room.	16.358702275975638
—Yes?	20.046607644329956
Buck Mulligan said.	4.11502558203882
What did I say?	16.30412008418556
I forget.	11.625935299839336
—You said, Stephen answered, _O, it’s only Dedalus whose mother is beastly dead._ A flush which made him seem younger and more engaging rose to Buck Mulligan’s cheek.	9.963538403440197
—Did I say that?	11.86324143568736
he asked.	5.571194519539272
Well?	18.814633242637697
What harm is that?	7.437501203237675
He shook his constraint from him nervously.	9.795626114827975
—And what is death, he asked, your mother’s or yours or my own?	15.428270052444928
You saw only your mother die.	9.121905554133146
I see them pop off every day in the Mater and Richmond and cut up into tripes in the dissectingroom.	13.120708368141868
It’s a beastly thing and nothing else.	10.984590478905979
It simply doesn’t matter.	10.900722984663336
You wouldn’t kneel down to pray for your mother on her deathbed when she asked you.	13.26097087878602
Why?	12.512270304170855
Because you have the cursed jesuit strain in you, only it’s injected the wrong way.	10.515971419832585
To me it’s all a mockery and beastly.	10.178266835806657
Her cerebral lobes are not functioning.	10.949209129687715
She calls the doctor sir Peter Teazle and picks buttercups off the quilt.	8.27289054264757
Humour her till it’s over.	8.40240291710064
You crossed her last wish in death and yet you sulk with me because I don’t whinge like some hired mute from Lalouette’s.	7.525656353496083
Absurd! I suppose I did say it.	9.73777348317188
I didn’t mean to offend the memory of your mother.	9.333753662865446
He had spoken himself into boldness.	12.367664466548963
Stephen, shielding the gaping wounds which the words had left in his heart, said very coldly: —I am not thinking of the offence to my mother.	14.055125458645346
—Of what then?	13.660116787180733
Buck Mulligan asked.	9.055337341580438
—Of the offence to me, Stephen answered.	9.16669844315505
Buck Mulligan swung round on his heel.	19.887845059568402
—O, an impossible person! he exclaimed.	14.019177122624034
Stephen stood at his post, gazing over the calm sea towards the headland.	14.035645418706483
Sea and headland now grew dim.	8.155771467838486
Pulses were beating in his eyes, veiling their sight, and he felt the fever of his cheeks.	11.16233422862095
A voice within the tower called loudly: —Are you up there, Mulligan?	14.742622054729267
—I’m coming, Buck Mulligan answered.	10.792826992090827
He turned towards Stephen and said: —Look at the sea.	12.525222082281818
Chuck Loyola, Kinch, and come on down.	8.716237782396272
The Sassenach wants his morning rashers.	7.785576598999252
His head halted again for a moment at the top of the staircase, level with the roof: —Don’t mope over it all day, he said.	12.72525553305042
I’m inconsequent.	23.31903927922339
Give up the moody brooding.	13.70901972889033
His head vanished but the drone of his descending voice boomed out of the stairhead: And no more turn aside and brood Upon love’s bitter mystery For Fergus rules the brazen cars.	10.500879227162558
Woodshadows floated silently by through the morning peace from the stairhead seaward where he gazed.	13.74269718805002
Inshore and farther out the mirror of water whitened, spurned by lightshod hurrying feet.	7.160908597702475
White breast of the dim sea.	11.848798713724955
The twining stresses, two by two.	6.486017834746071
A hand plucking the harpstrings, merging their twining chords.	5.191651483854875
Wavewhite wedded words shimmering on the dim tide.	12.55960151618416
A cloud began to cover the sun slowly, wholly, shadowing the bay in deeper green.	6.617006815747197
It lay beneath him, a bowl of bitter waters.	11.160729846482143
Fergus’ song: I sang it alone in the house, holding down the long dark chords.	12.206937870981262
Her door was open: she wanted to hear my music.	10.945623831430892
Silent with awe and pity I went to her bedside.	12.468740788597902
She was crying in her wretched bed.	12.488001831460467
For those words, Stephen: love’s bitter mystery.	13.644582223132945
Where now?	8.705951375757234
Her secrets: old featherfans, tasselled dancecards, powdered with musk, a gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer.	6.469905679027972
A birdcage hung in the sunny window of her house when she was a girl.	13.18888808138664
She heard old Royce sing in the pantomime of Turko the Terrible and laughed with others when he sang: I am the boy That can enjoy Invisibility.	9.460171700245297
Phantasmal mirth, folded away: muskperfumed.	8.222373048055493
And no more turn aside and brood.	9.717287835243782
Memories beset his brooding brain.	6.236036847035632
Her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had approached the sacrament.	15.562370855103305
A cored apple, filled with brown sugar, roasting for her at the hob on a dark autumn evening.	9.80250232408583
Her shapely fingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children’s shirts.	13.060022615194939
In a dream, silently, she had come to him, her wasted body within its loose graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath, bent over him with mute secret words, a faint odour of wetted ashes.	9.482008414073388
Her glazing eyes, staring out of death, to shake and bend my soul.	10.347450563949588
The ghostcandle to light her agony.	7.6694954261761445
Ghostly light on the tortured face.	9.814785898017524
Her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror, while all prayed on their knees.	7.481590608261233
Her eyes on me to strike me down.	12.293670885643664
_Liliata rutilantium te confessorum turma circumdet: iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat._ Ghoul! Chewer of corpses! No, mother! Let me be and let me live.	7.30796878989063
—Kinch ahoy! Buck Mulligan’s voice sang from within the tower.	9.673947111690069
It came nearer up the staircase, calling again.	7.45454186321977
Stephen, still trembling at his soul’s cry, heard warm running sunlight and in the air behind him friendly words.	13.866615407795194

Breakfast is ready.	7.790341086578495
Haines is apologising for waking us last night.	5.2362543110731155
It’s all right.	7.745559458195826

For my sake and for all our sakes.	15.099698464772734

He says it’s very clever.	11.962919486458793

How much?	17.890456849905004
Four quid?	14.207365831239104
Lend us one.	6.685656878661224

He flung up his hands and tramped down the stone stairs, singing out of tune with a Cockney accent: O, won’t we have a merry time, Drinking whisky, beer and wine! On coronation, Coronation day! O, won’t we have a merry time On coronation day! Warm sunshine merrying over the sea.	9.493346936025953
The nickel shavingbowl shone, forgotten, on the parapet.	8.161992253893198
Why should I bring it down?	12.323279220574184
Or leave it there all day, forgotten friendship?	14.367222656484527
He went over to it, held it in his hands awhile, feeling its coolness, smelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck.	11.132263405685881
So I carried the boat of incense then at Clongowes.	9.867431474120258
I am another now and yet the same.	11.383096224835267
A servant too.	4.586920176420202
A server of a servant.	13.611999347400996
In the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower Buck Mulligan’s gowned form moved briskly to and fro about the hearth, hiding and revealing its yellow glow.	10.927506625141
Two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor from the high barbacans: and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of coalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated, turning.	8.600016437808298
—We’ll be choked, Buck Mulligan said.	6.168173660758824
Haines, open that door, will you?	7.91186766561177
Stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker.	13.081077989508097
A tall figure rose from the hammock where it had been sitting, went to the doorway and pulled open the inner doors.	13.094367455770175
—Have you the key?	14.071795861234952
a voice asked.	7.582065859547325
—Dedalus has it, Buck Mulligan said.	6.330480638176656
Janey Mack, I’m choked! He howled, without looking up from the fire: —Kinch! —It’s in the lock, Stephen said, coming forward.	13.090847865605204
The key scraped round harshly twice and, when the heavy door had been set ajar, welcome light and bright air entered.	8.763660733015595
Haines stood at the doorway, looking out.	9.755790638182521
Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and sat down to wait.	8.436109247763921
Buck Mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside him.	9.961790971496747
Then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table, set them down heavily and sighed with relief.	11.362676832281895
—I’m melting, he said, as the candle remarked when...	7.084894097332095
But, hush! Not a word more on that subject! Kinch, wake up! Bread, butter, honey.	10.375442128244542
Haines, come in.	7.397379718537674
The grub is ready.	6.749467059208617
Bless us, O Lord, and these thy gifts.	15.115199014062327
Where’s the sugar?	18.894819080333153
Stephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from the locker.	12.948097071813882
Buck Mulligan sat down in a sudden pet.	20.070291046923508
—What sort of a kip is this?	18.0322081100736
he said.	3.3900725752648877
I told her to come after eight.	14.726578535068654
—We can drink it black, Stephen said thirstily.	14.439824822759764
There’s a lemon in the locker.	18.494217916278515
—O, damn you and your Paris fads! Buck Mulligan said.	7.060512652962205
I want Sandycove milk.	12.889827569799067
—The blessings of God on you! Buck Mulligan cried, jumping up from his chair.	14.522667860230298
Sit down.	6.26706705748047
Pour out the tea there.	8.166595797004673
The sugar is in the bag.	12.932461033878454
Here, I can’t go fumbling at the damned eggs.	17.822857054092033
He hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three plates, saying: —_In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti._ Haines sat down to pour out the tea.	9.237349184196379
—I’m giving you two lumps each, he said.	7.382189226945982
But, I say, Mulligan, you do make strong tea, don’t you?	12.428104934745141
Buck Mulligan, hewing thick slices from the loaf, said in an old woman’s wheedling voice: —When I makes tea I makes tea, as old mother Grogan said.	11.151552611630253
And when I makes water I makes water.	10.426311830744917
—By Jove, it is tea, Haines said.	7.976565274551039
Buck Mulligan went on hewing and wheedling: —_So I do, Mrs Cahill,_ says she.	11.57684163359761
_Begob, ma’am,_ says Mrs Cahill, _God send you don’t make them in the one pot._ He lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled on his knife.	8.926116537434867
—That’s folk, he said very earnestly, for your book, Haines.	14.518139735019988
Five lines of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of Dundrum.	10.436273627671277
Printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind.	14.099986905013655
—I doubt it, said Stephen gravely.	16.657523720663068
—Do you now?	11.518860709152314
Buck Mulligan said in the same tone.	16.99160176280443
Your reasons, pray?	12.957604447575635
—I fancy, Stephen said as he ate, it did not exist in or out of the Mabinogion.	17.153167264882633
Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann.	14.552340139222213
Buck Mulligan’s face smiled with delight.	13.203886005874844
Do you think she was?	20.26996791601472
Quite charming! Then, suddenly overclouding all his features, he growled in a hoarsened rasping voice as he hewed again vigorously at the loaf: _—For old Mary Ann She doesn’t care a damn.	12.126094673780605
But, hising up her petticoats..._ He crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned.	9.036070743305526
The doorway was darkened by an entering form.	7.5230165281757895
—The milk, sir! —Come in, ma’am, Mulligan said.	10.220891550666641
Kinch, get the jug.	18.641643434873465
An old woman came forward and stood by Stephen’s elbow.	17.98866149085524
—That’s a lovely morning, sir, she said.	7.53255987587835
Glory be to God.	7.112573816816043
—To whom?	18.97471167695028
Mulligan said, glancing at her.	9.053007442930097
Ah, to be sure! Stephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker.	14.611577812666456
—The islanders, Mulligan said to Haines casually, speak frequently of the collector of prepuces.	11.649666812621737
—How much, sir?	12.062431968640189
asked the old woman.	12.313897442139536
—A quart, Stephen said.	6.227765862560246
He watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white milk, not hers.	11.604867111459034
Old shrunken paps.	11.174647867337557
She poured again a measureful and a tilly.	12.669568723761206
Old and secret she had entered from a morning world, maybe a messenger.	11.184843315852214
She praised the goodness of the milk, pouring it out.	7.420938317799518
Crouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field, a witch on her toadstool, her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs.	14.18292834411225
They lowed about her whom they knew, dewsilky cattle.	8.013690050246392
Silk of the kine and poor old woman, names given her in old times.	11.364983707349722
A wandering crone, lowly form of an immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer, their common cuckquean, a messenger from the secret morning.	9.657048271302026
To serve or to upbraid, whether he could not tell: but scorned to beg her favour.	9.109070547869335
—It is indeed, ma’am, Buck Mulligan said, pouring milk into their cups.	11.006203621369325
—Taste it, sir, she said.	5.897599275455206
He drank at her bidding.	17.370837876429952
—If we could live on good food like that, he said to her somewhat loudly, we wouldn’t have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten guts.	11.391090331679438
Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with dust, horsedung and consumptives’ spits.	8.273280514301492
—Are you a medical student, sir?	10.034274755943592
the old woman asked.	10.925212885855288
—I am, ma’am, Buck Mulligan answered.	8.857292546654177
—Look at that now, she said.	7.265464418099808
Stephen listened in scornful silence.	5.7869229952306425
She bows her old head to a voice that speaks to her loudly, her bonesetter, her medicineman: me she slights.	12.103395427137833
To the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there is of her but her woman’s unclean loins, of man’s flesh made not in God’s likeness, the serpent’s prey.	15.947731652699497
And to the loud voice that now bids her be silent with wondering unsteady eyes.	8.939273027947287
—Do you understand what he says?	21.574932581051478
Stephen asked her.	6.639697784763984
—Is it French you are talking, sir?	11.295417399949182
the old woman said to Haines.	14.22946919189602
Haines spoke to her again a longer speech, confidently.	11.623528295352203
—Irish, Buck Mulligan said.	4.909142836631793
Is there Gaelic on you?	7.717332413966959
—I thought it was Irish, she said, by the sound of it.	12.21251568500563
Are you from the west, sir?	15.988413974644157
—I am an Englishman, Haines answered.	12.556053928966104
—He’s English, Buck Mulligan said, and he thinks we ought to speak Irish in Ireland.	11.494834691412423
—Sure we ought to, the old woman said, and I’m ashamed I don’t speak the language myself.	10.129948857356466
I’m told it’s a grand language by them that knows.	12.777941135505408
—Grand is no name for it, said Buck Mulligan.	10.697107652071793
Wonderful entirely.	15.07044042909492
Fill us out some more tea, Kinch.	9.641980642763977
Would you like a cup, ma’am?	13.61531384642434
—No, thank you, sir, the old woman said, slipping the ring of the milkcan on her forearm and about to go.	12.397122652419823
We had better pay her, Mulligan, hadn’t we?	12.981621792210833
Stephen filled again the three cups.	12.410508822597432
—Bill, sir?	7.351041821790252
she said, halting.	22.701235962873174
That’s a shilling and one and two is two and two, sir.	9.587258860237304
Buck Mulligan sighed and, having filled his mouth with a crust thickly buttered on both sides, stretched forth his legs and began to search his trouser pockets.	10.488561483329482
—Pay up and look pleasant, Haines said to him, smiling.	9.934872221890867
Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the thick rich milk.	9.165866238645421
Buck Mulligan brought up a florin, twisted it round in his fingers and cried: —A miracle! He passed it along the table towards the old woman, saying: —Ask nothing more of me, sweet.	14.597915436281774
All I can give you I give.	15.985491339763174
Stephen laid the coin in her uneager hand.	8.671774218497754
—We’ll owe twopence, he said.	6.522012720631896
—Time enough, sir, she said, taking the coin.	10.453539527376572
Time enough.	9.495695440594261
Good morning, sir.	5.170989786034188
I’m stony.	23.754530031965217
Hurry out to your school kip and bring us back some money.	8.360201988764981
Today the bards must drink and junket.	8.814354804530337
Ireland expects that every man this day will do his duty.	9.101432438391164
—That reminds me, Haines said, rising, that I have to visit your national library today.	12.950129503873036
—Our swim first, Buck Mulligan said.	5.799265690829076
He turned to Stephen and asked blandly: —Is this the day for your monthly wash, Kinch?	12.68478930995381
Then he said to Haines: —The unclean bard makes a point of washing once a month.	12.183974989762278
—All Ireland is washed by the gulfstream, Stephen said as he let honey trickle over a slice of the loaf.	13.127785176250354
Haines from the corner where he was knotting easily a scarf about the loose collar of his tennis shirt spoke: —I intend to make a collection of your sayings if you will let me.	13.111101467251036
Speaking to me.	4.4951574399550145
They wash and tub and scrub.	8.212875264303626
Agenbite of inwit.	9.508471597620137
Conscience.	32.172570290454246
Yet here’s a spot.	11.35701945676208
—That one about the cracked lookingglass of a servant being the symbol of Irish art is deuced good.	11.503367148617532
Buck Mulligan kicked Stephen’s foot under the table and said with warmth of tone: —Wait till you hear him on Hamlet, Haines.	14.841471466610697
—Well, I mean it, Haines said, still speaking to Stephen.	12.497498716206373
I was just thinking of it when that poor old creature came in.	12.096573128181303
Stephen asked.	5.479503230507703
Haines laughed and, as he took his soft grey hat from the holdfast of the hammock, said: —I don’t know, I’m sure.	12.079114055120172
He strolled out to the doorway.	12.338718834840185
Buck Mulligan bent across to Stephen and said with coarse vigour: —You put your hoof in it now.	10.359141643785126
What did you say that for?	16.935067453833586
Stephen said.	3.3990640623497015
The problem is to get money.	11.684929119434775
From whom?	13.283064669336406
From the milkwoman or from him.	6.758270676308704
It’s a toss up, I think.	10.645296872982076
—I blow him out about you, Buck Mulligan said, and then you come along with your lousy leer and your gloomy jesuit jibes.	12.548293738619908
—I see little hope, Stephen said, from her or from him.	10.21549688476733
Buck Mulligan sighed tragically and laid his hand on Stephen’s arm.	12.499870606380314
—From me, Kinch, he said.	6.636384849036527
In a suddenly changed tone he added: —To tell you the God’s truth I think you’re right.	12.05462423983245
Damn all else they are good for.	10.17710305324936
Why don’t you play them as I do?	12.780491987034114
To hell with them all.	7.282975191955062
Let us get out of the kip.	18.65753518473011
He stood up, gravely ungirdled and disrobed himself of his gown, saying resignedly: —Mulligan is stripped of his garments.	12.663625801569523
He emptied his pockets on to the table.	7.613131337116619
—There’s your snotrag, he said.	6.303651528532654
And putting on his stiff collar and rebellious tie he spoke to them, chiding them, and to his dangling watchchain.	10.809086202781263
His hands plunged and rummaged in his trunk while he called for a clean handkerchief.	12.906244654672353
God, we’ll simply have to dress the character.	12.598614971946434
I want puce gloves and green boots.	11.077288035142857
Contradiction.	32.172570290454246
Do I contradict myself?	12.015766136822673
Very well then, I contradict myself.	12.109687426853947
A limp black missile flew out of his talking hands.	7.6049104564064125
—And there’s your Latin quarter hat, he said.	7.8773091120695575
Stephen picked it up and put it on.	8.416797011041432
Haines called to them from the doorway: —Are you coming, you fellows?	20.23695792109843
—I’m ready, Buck Mulligan answered, going towards the door.	11.564616360116213
Come out, Kinch.	12.41279672789524
You have eaten all we left, I suppose.	9.822255107005
Resigned he passed out with grave words and gait, saying, wellnigh with sorrow: —And going forth he met Butterly.	9.235361789537604
Stephen, taking his ashplant from its leaningplace, followed them out and, as they went down the ladder, pulled to the slow iron door and locked it.	10.801144432321738
He put the huge key in his inner pocket.	11.982653086021484
At the foot of the ladder Buck Mulligan asked: —Did you bring the key?	17.69560351563296
—I have it, Stephen said, preceding them.	10.769069148990273
He walked on.	5.968325595406214
Behind him he heard Buck Mulligan club with his heavy bathtowel the leader shoots of ferns or grasses.	11.176756577343758
—Down, sir! How dare you, sir! Haines asked: —Do you pay rent for this tower?	13.364225211150602
—Twelve quid, Buck Mulligan said.	3.96715835920303
—To the secretary of state for war, Stephen added over his shoulder.	9.282675773618996
They halted while Haines surveyed the tower and said at last: —Rather bleak in wintertime, I should say.	9.054417784198428
Martello you call it?	7.686163309293345
—Billy Pitt had them built, Buck Mulligan said, when the French were on the sea.	8.083966050910751
But ours is the _omphalos_.	13.672879437360116
—What is your idea of Hamlet?	17.224752654035715
Haines asked Stephen.	8.216673741483776
—No, no, Buck Mulligan shouted in pain.	11.1688032782671
Wait till I have a few pints in me first.	13.094605979305182
He turned to Stephen, saying, as he pulled down neatly the peaks of his primrose waistcoat: —You couldn’t manage it under three pints, Kinch, could you?	11.529954870343255
—It has waited so long, Stephen said listlessly, it can wait longer.	11.877154316763487
—You pique my curiosity, Haines said amiably.	12.056730561444208
Is it some paradox?	17.997443963878396
—Pooh! Buck Mulligan said.	4.126106762638631
We have grown out of Wilde and paradoxes.	15.618807880864566
It’s quite simple.	19.30521865389205
He proves by algebra that Hamlet’s grandson is Shakespeare’s grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own father.	12.21704770570192
—What?	12.016783147492532
Haines said, beginning to point at Stephen.	11.75439218889792
He himself?	14.47062798106989
Buck Mulligan slung his towel stolewise round his neck and, bending in loose laughter, said to Stephen’s ear: —O, shade of Kinch the elder! Japhet in search of a father! —We’re always tired in the morning, Stephen said to Haines.	10.73257475127474
And it is rather long to tell.	14.59387084340778
Buck Mulligan, walking forward again, raised his hands.	11.32825917141496
—The sacred pint alone can unbind the tongue of Dedalus, he said.	5.5982926182357815
—I mean to say, Haines explained to Stephen as they followed, this tower and these cliffs here remind me somehow of Elsinore.	12.561474715875322
_That beetles o’er his base into the sea,_ isn’t it?	8.509588822429892
In the bright silent instant Stephen saw his own image in cheap dusty mourning between their gay attires.	11.638407024510181
—It’s a wonderful tale, Haines said, bringing them to halt again.	9.95448046323968
Eyes, pale as the sea the wind had freshened, paler, firm and prudent.	7.690879845569434
The seas’ ruler, he gazed southward over the bay, empty save for the smokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail tacking by the Muglins.	14.730124247337965
—I read a theological interpretation of it somewhere, he said bemused.	16.61468624334878
The Father and the Son idea.	12.20428282731209
The Son striving to be atoned with the Father.	14.205565091578016
Buck Mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face.	10.012605432785612
He looked at them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety.	9.913931041247631
He moved a doll’s head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice: _—I’m the queerest young fellow that ever you heard.	11.302474442961303
My mother’s a jew, my father’s a bird.	14.290584362890183
With Joseph the joiner I cannot agree.	8.754618707180853
So here’s to disciples and Calvary._ He held up a forefinger of warning.	10.040019349469182
_—If anyone thinks that I amn’t divine He’ll get no free drinks when I’m making the wine But have to drink water and wish it were plain That I make when the wine becomes water again._ He tugged swiftly at Stephen’s ashplant in farewell and, running forward to a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or wings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted: _—Goodbye, now, goodbye! Write down all I said And tell Tom, Dick and Harry I rose from the dead.	11.214457746676452
What’s bred in the bone cannot fail me to fly And Olivet’s breezy...	10.612773190701411
Goodbye, now, goodbye!_ He capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole, fluttering his winglike hands, leaping nimbly, Mercury’s hat quivering in the fresh wind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries.	9.173332594856701
Haines, who had been laughing guardedly, walked on beside Stephen and said: —We oughtn’t to laugh, I suppose.	11.042352991734806
He’s rather blasphemous.	20.255797232927744
I’m not a believer myself, that is to say.	9.927734843601106
What did he call it?	11.159368929213205
Joseph the Joiner?	16.4844632925734
—The ballad of joking Jesus, Stephen answered.	10.362650016794372
—O, Haines said, you have heard it before?	18.05289047986804
—Three times a day, after meals, Stephen said drily.	13.452325771720613
—You’re not a believer, are you?	9.26518095118207
Haines asked.	5.670210055907986
I mean, a believer in the narrow sense of the word.	16.01638851962371
Creation from nothing and miracles and a personal God.	8.747364926315926
—There’s only one sense of the word, it seems to me, Stephen said.	9.476491639876201
Haines stopped to take out a smooth silver case in which twinkled a green stone.	9.400538616196334
He sprang it open with his thumb and offered it.	7.219749639035543
—Thank you, Stephen said, taking a cigarette.	10.844935050356078
Haines helped himself and snapped the case to.	6.810836208659534
He put it back in his sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang it open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk towards Stephen in the shell of his hands.	9.868438967806823
—Yes, of course, he said, as they went on again.	8.968665073209547
Either you believe or you don’t, isn’t it?	6.630324843021535
Personally I couldn’t stomach that idea of a personal God.	11.465883650707179
You don’t stand for that, I suppose?	15.504866577819735
—You behold in me, Stephen said with grim displeasure, a horrible example of free thought.	11.629558710000701
He walked on, waiting to be spoken to, trailing his ashplant by his side.	13.493407097214597
Its ferrule followed lightly on the path, squealing at his heels.	9.78348770934411
My familiar, after me, calling, Steeeeeeeeeeeephen! A wavering line along the path.	10.099544406077156
They will walk on it tonight, coming here in the dark.	11.283002902543872
He wants that key.	9.648759113812607
It is mine.	15.476283582558581
I paid the rent.	10.216932151879254
Now I eat his salt bread.	10.07637148922324
Give him the key too.	8.246064373443117
All.	25.535385961793953
He will ask for it.	5.88496847292526
That was in his eyes.	9.714407380310066
Stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not all unkind.	13.670791577304819
—After all, I should think you are able to free yourself.	14.27870766337645
You are your own master, it seems to me.	9.460337234021702
—I am a servant of two masters, Stephen said, an English and an Italian.	13.904361542732135
—Italian?	15.758647907172964
Haines said.	3.4625634008272983
A crazy queen, old and jealous.	9.74113994663659
Kneel down before me.	4.580660844761962
—And a third, Stephen said, there is who wants me for odd jobs.	12.599889694884618
—Italian?	15.758647907172964
Haines said again.	8.905318161676215
What do you mean?	17.60719342547977
—The imperial British state, Stephen answered, his colour rising, and the holy Roman catholic and apostolic church.	11.430337184283616
Haines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he spoke.	8.733900834185057
—I can quite understand that, he said calmly.	17.687162956125654
We feel in England that we have treated you rather unfairly.	9.584718506121819
It seems history is to blame.	9.47100508396824
The proud potent titles clanged over Stephen’s memory the triumph of their brazen bells: _et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam ecclesiam:_ the slow growth and change of rite and dogma like his own rare thoughts, a chemistry of stars.	6.712934374016517
Symbol of the apostles in the mass for pope Marcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in affirmation: and behind their chant the vigilant angel of the church militant disarmed and menaced her heresiarchs.	9.97759553717671
A horde of heresies fleeing with mitres awry: Photius and the brood of mockers of whom Mulligan was one, and Arius, warring his life long upon the consubstantiality of the Son with the Father, and Valentine, spurning Christ’s terrene body, and the subtle African heresiarch Sabellius who held that the Father was Himself His own Son.	9.24098214739603
Words Mulligan had spoken a moment since in mockery to the stranger.	10.665600976785345
Idle mockery.	12.621260247635798
The void awaits surely all them that weave the wind: a menace, a disarming and a worsting from those embattled angels of the church, Michael’s host, who defend her ever in the hour of conflict with their lances and their shields.	11.872859065160965
Hear, hear! Prolonged applause.	7.228363303751386
_Zut! Nom de Dieu!_ —Of course I’m a Britisher, Haines’s voice said, and I feel as one.	10.270054496870587
I don’t want to see my country fall into the hands of German jews either.	10.82858121581678
That’s our national problem, I’m afraid, just now.	8.5416081972429
—She’s making for Bullock harbour.	14.008442114593956
The boatman nodded towards the north of the bay with some disdain.	14.187046213707976
—There’s five fathoms out there, he said.	6.3075213494845634
It’ll be swept up that way when the tide comes in about one.	12.3765712429062
It’s nine days today.	11.732158744011539
The man that was drowned.	16.36602040791876
A sail veering about the blank bay waiting for a swollen bundle to bob up, roll over to the sun a puffy face, saltwhite.	10.232032711321887
Here I am.	9.414036746491485
They followed the winding path down to the creek.	14.380674386868066
Buck Mulligan stood on a stone, in shirtsleeves, his unclipped tie rippling over his shoulder.	12.207412200233337
A young man clinging to a spur of rock near him, moved slowly frogwise his green legs in the deep jelly of the water.	11.100162246693182
—Is the brother with you, Malachi?	14.309920481134922

Buck Mulligan sat down to unlace his boots.	11.721351183914537
An elderly man shot up near the spur of rock a blowing red face.	6.204805128085213
He scrambled up by the stones, water glistening on his pate and on its garland of grey hair, water rilling over his chest and paunch and spilling jets out of his black sagging loincloth.	10.150645281010757

Chucked medicine and going in for the army.	12.558430528004864
—Ah, go to God! Buck Mulligan said.	8.831298425440357

A swarthy boy opened a book and propped it nimbly under the breastwork of his satchel.	9.108064343813318
He recited jerks of verse with odd glances at the text: _—Weep no more, woful shepherds, weep no more For Lycidas, your sorrow, is not dead, Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor..._ It must be a movement then, an actuality of the possible as possible.	9.44470926594571
Aristotle’s phrase formed itself within the gabbled verses and floated out into the studious silence of the library of Saint Genevieve where he had read, sheltered from the sin of Paris, night by night.	9.94766290239097
By his elbow a delicate Siamese conned a handbook of strategy.	6.850226648439045

Cyril Sargent: his name and seal.	11.946082892575765

he asked.	5.571194519539272

—No, sir.	6.595748510743427
Ugly and futile: lean neck and tangled hair and a stain of ink, a snail’s bed.	9.932658146987947
But for her the race of the world would have trampled him underfoot, a squashed boneless snail.	13.061132273939323
She had loved his weak watery blood drained from her own.	8.201142755927341

A poor soul gone to heaven: and on a heath beneath winking stars a fox, red reek of rapine in his fur, with merciless bright eyes scraped in the earth, listened, scraped up the earth, listened, scraped and scraped.	9.509774267648057

Gone too from the world, Averroes and Moses Maimonides, dark men in mien and movement, flashing in their mocking mirrors the obscure soul of the world, a darkness shining in brightness which brightness could not comprehend.	9.002699105264611

_Amor matris:_ subjective and objective genitive.	11.235618758573686

My childhood bends beside me.	4.413056295461603

Hoarse, masked and armed, the planters’ covenant.	9.961587694025733
The black north and true blue bible.	9.581642156443182
Stephen sketched a brief gesture.	10.48932814095984
—I have rebel blood in me too, Mr Deasy said.	10.035297352487984
On the spindle side.	11.302888337514888
But I am descended from sir John Blackwood who voted for the union.	15.296558082965392
We are all Irish, all kings’ sons.	12.119862868339077
—Alas, Stephen said.	3.4453420989746464
—_Per vias rectas_, Mr Deasy said firmly, was his motto.	9.56592269931645
He voted for it and put on his topboots to ride to Dublin from the Ards of Down to do so.	10.777840260718554
Lal the ral the ra The rocky road to Dublin.	6.203844336239848
A gruff squire on horseback with shiny topboots.	6.344304452153952
Soft day, sir John! Soft day, your honour!...	5.954472546002862
Day!...	2.4344720040315546
Day!...	2.4344720040315546
Two topboots jog dangling on to Dublin.	7.466794308187112
Lal the ral the ra.	8.660790021542352
Lal the ral the raddy.	9.010500030496756
—That reminds me, Mr Deasy said.	8.11300319058169
You can do me a favour, Mr Dedalus, with some of your literary friends.	13.220081511092813
I have a letter here for the press.	17.437424889325463
I have just to copy the end.	9.995048126097874
He went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice and read off some words from the sheet on the drum of his typewriter.	17.835251881908093
—Sit down.	5.663577620188617
Excuse me, he said over his shoulder, _the dictates of common sense._ Just a moment.	7.759372810455588
He peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow and, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly, sometimes blowing as he screwed up the drum to erase an error.	11.262658680945231
Stephen seated himself noiselessly before the princely presence.	9.018786839491042
Elfin riders sat them, watchful of a sign.	11.790266069740987
He saw their speeds, backing king’s colours, and shouted with the shouts of vanished crowds.	11.395359846970042
—Full stop, Mr Deasy bade his keys.	10.253449439678672
_But prompt ventilation of this allimportant question..._ Where Cranly led me to get rich quick, hunting his winners among the mudsplashed brakes, amid the bawls of bookies on their pitches and reek of the canteen, over the motley slush.	8.669617802252523
Even money _Fair Rebel._ Ten to one the field.	6.262339898096683
Dicers and thimbleriggers we hurried by after the hoofs, the vying caps and jackets and past the meatfaced woman, a butcher’s dame, nuzzling thirstily her clove of orange.	8.89874990711879
Shouts rang shrill from the boys’ playfield and a whirring whistle.	11.43551012136467
Again: a goal.	13.6389145599001
I am among them, among their battling bodies in a medley, the joust of life.	11.70950883164967
You mean that knockkneed mother’s darling who seems to be slightly crawsick?	13.270443330353311
Jousts.	32.172570290454246
Time shocked rebounds, shock by shock.	6.126762966813408
Jousts, slush and uproar of battles, the frozen deathspew of the slain, a shout of spearspikes baited with men’s bloodied guts.	11.023720523101254

Stephen stood up.	5.328913521518655

Just look through it.	4.195910403441764
There can be no two opinions on the matter.	11.117846615452814
May I trespass on your valuable space.	10.29935063354093
That doctrine of _laissez faire_ which so often in our history.	6.8411642772193275
Our cattle trade.	8.489625661371049
The way of all our old industries.	15.038490257380696

Cassandra.	32.172570290454246
By a woman who was no better than she should be.	11.85261238355967

Courteous offer a fair trial.	9.701067404854983

And it can be cured.	16.745187634514494
It is cured.	21.6923361866218

They offer to come over here.	6.609258167561704

backstairs influence by...	2.7495599072623884
He raised his forefinger and beat the air oldly before his voice spoke.	10.252504721813084
—Mark my words, Mr Dedalus, he said.	5.601597281626786
England is in the hands of the jews.	15.506842399027732
In all the highest places: her finance, her press.	14.437716537114014
And they are the signs of a nation’s decay.	22.04448315581484
Wherever they gather they eat up the nation’s vital strength.	11.79861627744065
I have seen it coming these years.	10.06748325000062
As sure as we are standing here the jew merchants are already at their work of destruction.	11.301055366380426
Old England is dying.	9.282579573657042
He stepped swiftly off, his eyes coming to blue life as they passed a broad sunbeam.	12.402804327299098
He faced about and back again.	6.849440780191586

The harlot’s cry from street to street Shall weave old England’s windingsheet.	10.763269999866221
—A merchant, Stephen said, is one who buys cheap and sells dear, jew or gentile, is he not?	10.049278926256662
—They sinned against the light, Mr Deasy said gravely.	13.811389168147906
And you can see the darkness in their eyes.	13.133658227042991
And that is why they are wanderers on the earth to this day.	14.680892495445796
On the steps of the Paris stock exchange the goldskinned men quoting prices on their gemmed fingers.	8.356026457771128
Gabble of geese.	8.150313597010452

Not theirs: these clothes, this speech, these gestures.	8.544056351775346
Their full slow eyes belied the words, the gestures eager and unoffending, but knew the rancours massed about them and knew their zeal was vain.	7.727085408487517
Vain patience to heap and hoard.	6.778192501374678
Time surely would scatter all.	4.883684931563049
A hoard heaped by the roadside: plundered and passing on.	6.413333124570307
Their eyes knew their years of wandering and, patient, knew the dishonours of their flesh.	9.225887390499306

Stephen said.	3.3990640623497015
Mr Deasy asked.	7.633014101267768

Looking up again he set them free.	9.48200605199532
—I am happier than you are, he said.	8.30928323734954
We have committed many errors and many sins.	8.9064100551258
A woman brought sin into the world.	7.31805202696512
For a woman who was no better than she should be, Helen, the runaway wife of Menelaus, ten years the Greeks made war on Troy.	10.286486014203998
A faithless wife first brought the strangers to our shore here, MacMurrough’s wife and her leman, O’Rourke, prince of Breffni.	9.758406958863533
A woman too brought Parnell low.	8.823921170074424
Many errors, many failures but not the one sin.	8.918627926191586
I am a struggler now at the end of my days.	11.795418264712394

For Ulster will fight And Ulster will be right.	7.461501328610675

Diaphane, adiaphane.	10.18424733735438

Shut your eyes and see.	8.039323517611303
You are walking through it howsomever.	13.107860284673311
I am, a stride at a time.	10.835805199129524

Open your eyes.	6.061531380802674
No. Jesus! If I fell over a cliff that beetles o’er his base, fell through the _nebeneinander_ ineluctably! I am getting on nicely in the dark.	10.4356217110576
My ash sword hangs at my side.	7.022198906384292
Tap with it: they do.	10.125759910539196

—Who is that?	9.906033142419492
—Your son and heir.	12.836850107498455
—Where is he?	9.971790703840202
Mr Dedalus said, stretching over across.	11.852372716014063
The carriage, passing the open drains and mounds of rippedup roadway before the tenement houses, lurched round the corner and, swerving back to the tramtrack, rolled on noisily with chattering wheels.	7.671510666305314
Mr Dedalus fell back, saying: —Was that Mulligan cad with him?	13.51433655185359
His _fidus Achates_! —No, Mr Bloom said.	6.1246923030805664
He was alone.	15.013697987979329
—Down with his aunt Sally, I suppose, Mr Dedalus said, the Goulding faction, the drunken little costdrawer and Crissie, papa’s little lump of dung, the wise child that knows her own father.	10.17501086787633
Mr Bloom smiled joylessly on Ringsend road.	9.28505197555146
Wallace Bros: the bottleworks: Dodder bridge.	7.547977012956763
Richie Goulding and the legal bag.	15.087281304042316
Goulding, Collis and Ward he calls the firm.	7.965511211851643
His jokes are getting a bit damp.	10.922629872311282
Great card he was.	5.442926738299036
Waltzing in Stamer street with Ignatius Gallaher on a Sunday morning, the landlady’s two hats pinned on his head.	10.110855155732523
Out on the rampage all night.	10.569214393446806
Beginning to tell on him now: that backache of his, I fear.	11.344787547220102
Wife ironing his back.	5.038446289831748
Thinks he’ll cure it with pills.	15.781259110169126
All breadcrumbs they are.	5.917244099455636
About six hundred per cent profit.	10.948640331087246
—He’s in with a lowdown crowd, Mr Dedalus snarled.	15.352719700231786
That Mulligan is a contaminated bloody doubledyed ruffian by all accounts.	10.066610799876644
His name stinks all over Dublin.	10.448869719255754
But with the help of God and His blessed mother I’ll make it my business to write a letter one of those days to his mother or his aunt or whatever she is that will open her eye as wide as a gate.	12.609275011255775
I’ll tickle his catastrophe, believe you me.	7.115627511364145
He cried above the clatter of the wheels: —I won’t have her bastard of a nephew ruin my son.	10.853931732981863
A counterjumper’s son.	9.469905454599905
Selling tapes in my cousin, Peter Paul M’Swiney’s.	8.011426893032274
Not likely.	10.537498549673511
He ceased.	11.392086880381463

Noisy selfwilled man.	5.134240739552822
He is right.	10.551197342348999
Something to hand on.	7.385370481469403
If little Rudy had lived.	8.777407973634784
See him grow up.	5.353868577782647

Me in his eyes.	7.935346311506526
Strange feeling it would be.	7.400898944539076
From me.	4.5216291380000495
Just a chance.	14.333630466847397

And the sergeant grinning up.	8.057028866202534

From one extreme to the other.	7.939425315370554

—What’s wrong now?	14.013867684802193

Huuuh! out of that! Thursday, of course.	8.549012788459699
Tomorrow is killing day.	5.417204061496923
Springers.	32.172570290454246
Cuffe sold them about twentyseven quid each.	7.338043322972954
For Liverpool probably.	6.814763650974155
Roastbeef for old England.	10.925757323652281
They buy up all the juicy ones.	11.927039901864868
And then the fifth quarter lost: all that raw stuff, hide, hair, horns.	9.148712863738023
Comes to a big thing in a year.	18.521874706870793
Dead meat trade.	8.518579568890646
Byproducts of the slaughterhouses for tanneries, soap, margarine.	10.824410831573918

The carriage moved on through the drove.	14.532768978007509

Aboard of the _Bugabu._ Their eyes watched him.	8.884897371971434

Hire some old crock, safety.	9.052786139078762
Wren had one the other day at the auction but a lady’s.	9.785153818506744

Always in front of us.	7.726208815537066
The mourners knelt here and there in prayingdesks.	11.339099016524465
Mr Bloom stood behind near the font and, when all had knelt, dropped carefully his unfolded newspaper from his pocket and knelt his right knee upon it.	8.46939643816095
A server bearing a brass bucket with something in it came out through a door.	10.597944825968618
The whitesmocked priest came after him, tidying his stole with one hand, balancing with the other a little book against his toad’s belly.	12.080521513489748
Who’ll read the book?	26.71274487181057
I, said the rook.	13.069525993724033
They halted by the bier and the priest began to read out of his book with a fluent croak.	19.356453502159813
Father Coffey.	15.618527184337362
I knew his name was like a coffin.	15.481444587299638
_Dominenamine._ Bully about the muzzle he looks.	10.304139414500316
Bosses the show.	7.2829592070987355
Muscular christian.	15.141877057334794
Woe betide anyone that looks crooked at him: priest.	7.599971027021307
Thou art Peter.	12.854234958415269
Burst sideways like a sheep in clover Dedalus says he will.	10.257280374713025
With a belly on him like a poisoned pup.	17.25953802804985
Most amusing expressions that man finds.	10.566111976639679
Hhhn: burst sideways.	8.449654603101825
_—Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine._ Makes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin.	8.418056080403804
Requiem mass.	10.065540000170595
Crape weepers.	14.833002552262101
Your name on the altarlist.	21.579957220800463
Chilly place this.	6.914338597572539
Want to feed well, sitting in there all the morning in the gloom kicking his heels waiting for the next please.	16.34404220054386
Eyes of a toad too.	9.775273196871904
What swells him up that way?	12.172426532692384
Molly gets swelled after cabbage.	7.847704571327521
Air of the place maybe.	20.836260276677134
Looks full up of bad gas.	9.567517732393682
Must be an infernal lot of bad gas round the place.	11.489104546350157
Butchers, for instance: they get like raw beefsteaks.	13.255234826349781
Who was telling me?	10.118238790419724
Mervyn Browne.	14.833002552262101
Down in the vaults of saint Werburgh’s lovely old organ hundred and fifty they have to bore a hole in the coffins sometimes to let out the bad gas and burn it.	10.742707101533485
Out it rushes: blue.	7.534999937281475
One whiff of that and you’re a goner.	10.821422098027496
My kneecap is hurting me.	3.841387067224406
Ow. That’s better.	11.22657866683091
The priest took a stick with a knob at the end of it out of the boy’s bucket and shook it over the coffin.	15.323859540834832
Then he walked to the other end and shook it again.	12.017039871325935
Then he came back and put it back in the bucket.	16.95209782663047
As you were before you rested.	16.00277526483067
It’s all written down: he has to do it.	9.702390476575127
_—Et ne nos inducas in tentationem._ The server piped the answers in the treble.	9.472872310309558
I often thought it would be better to have boy servants.	15.512371271561014
Up to fifteen or so.	7.950035198878498
After that, of course ...	3.5833400535346187
Holy water that was, I expect.	12.225946073670091
Shaking sleep out of it.	4.701838810431034
He must be fed up with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up.	10.184841404391419
Every mortal day a fresh batch: middleaged men, old women, children, women dead in childbirth, men with beards, baldheaded businessmen, consumptive girls with little sparrows’ breasts.	6.53034714111082
All the year round he prayed the same thing over them all and shook water on top of them: sleep.	12.970641420229757
On Dignam now.	4.717610819991063
Says that over everybody.	9.027268727680909
Tiresome kind of a job.	12.06497957682642
But he has to say something.	17.580465878998854
The priest closed his book and went off, followed by the server.	15.847773532955905
Corny Kelleher opened the sidedoors and the gravediggers came in, hoisted the coffin again, carried it out and shoved it on their cart.	13.138684751730686
Corny Kelleher gave one wreath to the boy and one to the brother-in-law.	10.494650703431967
All followed them out of the sidedoors into the mild grey air.	11.546995829943647
He gazed gravely at the ground till the coffincart wheeled off to the left.	11.885381952450027
The metal wheels ground the gravel with a sharp grating cry and the pack of blunt boots followed the trundled barrow along a lane of sepulchres.	8.744565527741496
The ree the ra the ree the ra the roo.	5.86543419558368
Lord, I mustn’t lilt here.	14.68056942755207
—The O’Connell circle, Mr Dedalus said about him.	10.834381120335204
Mr Power’s soft eyes went up to the apex of the lofty cone.	17.656781467896508
—He’s at rest, he said, in the middle of his people, old Dan O’.	11.462609086399732
But his heart is buried in Rome.	10.007958382875199
Let Him take me whenever He likes.	9.883557519734985
Breaking down, he began to weep to himself quietly, stumbling a little in his walk.	12.003454476022691
Mr Power took his arm.	14.082900586810638
—She’s better where she is, he said kindly.	13.746521800097808
—I suppose so, Mr Dedalus said with a weak gasp.	18.22651843474354
I suppose she is in heaven if there is a heaven.	15.908690911310035
Corny Kelleher stepped aside from his rank and allowed the mourners to plod by.	8.096238748254914
—Sad occasions, Mr Kernan began politely.	12.247548935721277
Mr Bloom closed his eyes and sadly twice bowed his head.	10.82016996192453
—The others are putting on their hats, Mr Kernan said.	10.495863093226196
I suppose we can do so too.	11.193232226344865
This cemetery is a treacherous place.	8.61461155233566
They covered their heads.	8.021219149135364
—The reverend gentleman read the service too quickly, don’t you think?	13.59720993514691
Mr Kernan said with reproof.	16.517774690719513
Mr Bloom nodded gravely looking in the quick bloodshot eyes.	11.91097613553894
Secret eyes, secretsearching.	15.60815239349812
Mason, I think: not sure.	11.214666728619846
Beside him again.	5.943063581223544
In the same boat.	28.84672972495946
Hope he’ll say something else.	12.17698073139485
Mr Kernan added: —The service of the Irish church used in Mount Jerome is simpler, more impressive I must say.	9.822716841078941
Mr Bloom gave prudent assent.	16.697720860922946
The language of course was another thing.	9.376646165392021
Mr Kernan said with solemnity: —_I am the resurrection and the life_.	16.818116354140646
That touches a man’s inmost heart.	10.537096253675015
—It does, Mr Bloom said.	6.71690830326226
Your heart perhaps but what price the fellow in the six feet by two with his toes to the daisies?	13.600611191146184
No touching that.	4.484528595254492
Seat of the affections.	24.473745027231566
Broken heart.	7.213280191685069
A pump after all, pumping thousands of gallons of blood every day.	6.793360437489195
One fine day it gets bunged up: and there you are.	7.74049626788254
Lots of them lying around here: lungs, hearts, livers.	8.124962714570705
Old rusty pumps: damn the thing else.	6.652799003773246
The resurrection and the life.	7.6465243912465946
Once you are dead you are dead.	11.267823198724608
That last day idea.	9.394658974736034
Knocking them all up out of their graves.	13.953872205316985
Come forth, Lazarus! And he came fifth and lost the job.	9.471071170686388
Get up! Last day! Then every fellow mousing around for his liver and his lights and the rest of his traps.	13.10962078461403
Find damn all of himself that morning.	8.061619292186007
Pennyweight of powder in a skull.	12.109885461384154

Policeman’s shoulders.	15.158402353335982
With your tooraloom tooraloom.	8.066507871095862

Mr Kernan assured him.	6.302721963424902

I know his face.	7.171739521643282
Ned Lambert glanced back.	9.096215732857855

She’s his wife.	9.621714222859664

—My dear Simon, the caretaker answered in a low voice.	13.995824013953687
I don’t want your custom at all.	7.939434900357772
Saluting Ned Lambert and John Henry Menton he walked on at Martin Cunningham’s side puzzling two long keys at his back.	9.009086290844571
—Did you hear that one, he asked them, about Mulcahy from the Coombe?	19.136926853452806
—I did not, Martin Cunningham said.	7.397860274060229
They bent their silk hats in concert and Hynes inclined his ear.	5.4361207661786235
The caretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke in a discreet tone to their vacant smiles.	12.060751480562859
—They tell the story, he said, that two drunks came out here one foggy evening to look for the grave of a friend of theirs.	12.177736431815612
They asked for Mulcahy from the Coombe and were told where he was buried.	13.533954639857662
One of the drunks spelt out the name: Terence Mulcahy.	15.990550841303373
The other drunk was blinking up at a statue of Our Saviour the widow had got put up.	7.78300054246381
The caretaker blinked up at one of the sepulchres they passed.	12.958279825354905
He resumed: —And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, _Not a bloody bit like the man_, says he.	9.534974633058713
_That’s not Mulcahy_, says he, _whoever done it_.	11.3158237631697
Rewarded by smiles he fell back and spoke with Corny Kelleher, accepting the dockets given him, turning them over and scanning them as he walked.	9.350475148534551
—That’s all done with a purpose, Martin Cunningham explained to Hynes.	13.717466890747465
—I know, Hynes said.	7.453390376135771
—To cheer a fellow up, Martin Cunningham said.	6.59949558448319
It’s pure goodheartedness: damn the thing else.	9.721431474741356

Well, so it is.	10.052120816069275

ERIN, GREEN GEM OF THE SILVER SEA —The ghost walks, professor MacHugh murmured softly, biscuitfully to the dusty windowpane.	9.459488449153186

—Sorry, Mr Bloom said.	4.495070604005135

O’Molloy slapped the heavy pages over.	9.792468514358928

—It was the speech, mark you, the professor said, of a finished orator, full of courteous haughtiness and pouring in chastened diction I will not say the vials of his wrath but pouring the proud man’s contumely upon the new movement.	10.16781036770251
It was then a new movement.	20.2692532578387
We were weak, therefore worthless.	10.244880185196383
He closed his long thin lips an instant but, eager to be on, raised an outspanned hand to his spectacles and, with trembling thumb and ringfinger touching lightly the black rims, steadied them to a new focus.	10.383435403578627
IMPROMPTU In ferial tone he addressed J.	4.920814056776214
O’Molloy: —Taylor had come there, you must know, from a sickbed.	15.937327194660119

Briefly, as well as I can bring them to mind, his words were these.	17.929840854567892
His eyes bethought themselves once more.	7.542016337302538
Witless shellfish swam in the gross lenses to and fro, seeking outlet.	10.40897325703138
He began: _—Mr Chairman, ladies and gentlemen: Great was my admiration in listening to the remarks addressed to the youth of Ireland a moment since by my learned friend.	9.081388049914631
It seemed to me that I had been transported into a country far away from this country, into an age remote from this age, that I stood in ancient Egypt and that I was listening to the speech of some highpriest of that land addressed to the youthful Moses._ His listeners held their cigarettes poised to hear, their smokes ascending in frail stalks that flowered with his speech.	12.360320668618012
_And let our crooked smokes._ Noble words coming.	6.069489827398922
Look out.	5.540668548197516
Could you try your hand at it yourself?	13.186667312118866
_—And it seemed to me that I heard the voice of that Egyptian highpriest raised in a tone of like haughtiness and like pride.	12.371013400543047
I heard his words and their meaning was revealed to me._ FROM THE FATHERS It was revealed to me that those things are good which yet are corrupted which neither if they were supremely good nor unless they were good could be corrupted.	10.033813372038653
Ah, curse you! That’s saint Augustine.	18.580737876980905
_—Why will you jews not accept our culture, our religion and our language?	13.00950746856131
You are a tribe of nomad herdsmen: we are a mighty people.	9.825590556648766
You have no cities nor no wealth: our cities are hives of humanity and our galleys, trireme and quadrireme, laden with all manner merchandise furrow the waters of the known globe.	7.1361483624893465
You have but emerged from primitive conditions: we have a literature, a priesthood, an agelong history and a polity._ Nile.	11.704218462638742
Child, man, effigy.	14.1884658022638
By the Nilebank the babemaries kneel, cradle of bulrushes: a man supple in combat: stonehorned, stonebearded, heart of stone.	6.557639658758239
_—You pray to a local and obscure idol: our temples, majestic and mysterious, are the abodes of Isis and Osiris, of Horus and Ammon Ra. Yours serfdom, awe and humbleness: ours thunder and the seas.	6.590877769545997
Israel is weak and few are her children: Egypt is an host and terrible are her arms.	7.380552626783535
Vagrants and daylabourers are you called: the world trembles at our name._ A dumb belch of hunger cleft his speech.	8.979977280742409
He lifted his voice above it boldly: _—But, ladies and gentlemen, had the youthful Moses listened to and accepted that view of life, had he bowed his head and bowed his will and bowed his spirit before that arrogant admonition he would never have brought the chosen people out of their house of bondage, nor followed the pillar of the cloud by day.	9.888621586529304

Through spaces smaller than red globules of man’s blood they creepycrawl after Blake’s buttocks into eternity of which this vegetable world is but a shadow.	8.402889553662716
Hold to the now, the here, through which all future plunges to the past.	12.144737365869963
Mr Best came forward, amiable, towards his colleague.	10.722552483914162
—Haines is gone, he said.	4.896013713813424
—Is he?	11.265480306039917
—I was showing him Jubainville’s book.	15.595011213464785
He’s quite enthusiastic, don’t you know, about Hyde’s _Lovesongs of Connacht._ I couldn’t bring him in to hear the discussion.	12.689987779705064
He’s gone to Gill’s to buy it.	8.10468603085922
Bound thee forth, my booklet, quick To greet the callous public.	7.404522703850382
Writ, I ween, ’twas not my wish In lean unlovely English.	8.552804529474873

We feel in England.	8.813397207244083
Penitent thief.	15.009292486789496

I smoked his baccy.	9.322994411503998

The rarefied air of the academy and the arena produce the sixshilling novel, the musichall song.	10.73268508578423
France produces the finest flower of corruption in Mallarmé but the desirable life is revealed only to the poor of heart, the life of Homer’s Phæacians.	10.524734715334892
From these words Mr Best turned an unoffending face to Stephen.	7.5575546218309135
—Mallarmé, don’t you know, he said, has written those wonderful prose poems Stephen MacKenna used to read to me in Paris.	8.458156066843552

They advertised it.	3.7329805859928933

It’s so French.	15.657292815405933
_Hamlet ou_...	2.3608030459348393

John Eglinton laughed.	13.928653210513273

List! List! O List! My flesh hears him: creeping, hears.	9.737032369529572
If thou didst ever...	3.122710302220635
—What is a ghost?	21.85616942783243
Stephen said with tingling energy.	15.079146031325966
One who has faded into impalpability through death, through absence, through change of manners.	9.40724131653828
Elizabethan London lay as far from Stratford as corrupt Paris lies from virgin Dublin.	6.158912777026008
Who is the ghost from _limbo patrum_, returning to the world that has forgotten him?	9.375181280628183
Who is King Hamlet?	17.773471538584666
John Eglinton shifted his spare body, leaning back to judge.	13.485967338931882
Lifted.	32.172570290454246
The flag is up on the playhouse by the bankside.	17.43133955186813

Work in all you know.	7.850505246538908

Composition of place.	6.8008886660720105
Ignatius Loyola, make haste to help me! —The play begins.	11.979783548241171
A player comes on under the shadow, made up in the castoff mail of a court buck, a wellset man with a bass voice.	12.938035367813294
It is the ghost, the king, a king and no king, and the player is Shakespeare who has studied _Hamlet_ all the years of his life which were not vanity in order to play the part of the spectre.	13.916794053768243
He speaks the words to Burbage, the young player who stands before him beyond the rack of cerecloth, calling him by a name: Hamlet, I am thy father’s spirit, bidding him list.	10.294709011560668
To a son he speaks, the son of his soul, the prince, young Hamlet and to the son of his body, Hamnet Shakespeare, who has died in Stratford that his namesake may live for ever.	11.055507310555301
Is it possible that that player Shakespeare, a ghost by absence, and in the vesture of buried Denmark, a ghost by death, speaking his own words to his own son’s name (had Hamnet Shakespeare lived he would have been prince Hamlet’s twin), is it possible, I want to know, or probable that he did not draw or foresee the logical conclusion of those premises: you are the dispossessed son: I am the murdered father: your mother is the guilty queen, Ann Shakespeare, born Hathaway?	12.319641624468536
—But this prying into the family life of a great man, Russell began impatiently.	16.023086189301385
Art thou there, truepenny?	14.957185770623104

I mean, we have the plays.	13.723376451849687
I mean when we read the poetry of _King Lear_ what is it to us how the poet lived?	14.47184172966189
As for living our servants can do that for us, Villiers de l’Isle has said.	6.774864035519606
Peeping and prying into greenroom gossip of the day, the poet’s drinking, the poet’s debts.	14.652319453413533

A man of genius makes no mistakes.	12.157893248984005

Portals of discovery opened to let in the quaker librarian, softcreakfooted, bald, eared and assiduous.	7.037358367054215
—A shrew, John Eglinton said shrewdly, is not a useful portal of discovery, one should imagine.	10.659211749694832
What useful discovery did Socrates learn from Xanthippe?	7.517578161085193
—Dialectic, Stephen answered: and from his mother how to bring thoughts into the world.	12.90347802501934
What he learnt from his other wife Myrto (_absit nomen!_), Socratididion’s Epipsychidion, no man, not a woman, will ever know.	11.402689652610798
But neither the midwife’s lore nor the caudlelectures saved him from the archons of Sinn Fein and their naggin of hemlock.	8.783663887641117
—But Ann Hathaway?	16.00489013384428
Mr Best’s quiet voice said forgetfully.	14.879517176304901
Yes, we seem to be forgetting her as Shakespeare himself forgot her.	12.008353107870024
His look went from brooder’s beard to carper’s skull, to remind, to chide them not unkindly, then to the baldpink lollard costard, guiltless though maligned.	9.513829715408546
—He had a good groatsworth of wit, Stephen said, and no truant memory.	11.594137045227324
He carried a memory in his wallet as he trudged to Romeville whistling _The girl I left behind me._ If the earthquake did not time it we should know where to place poor Wat, sitting in his form, the cry of hounds, the studded bridle and her blue windows.	9.795610176661787
That memory, _Venus and Adonis_, lay in the bedchamber of every light-of-love in London.	7.6935737320751585

Good: he left her and gained the world of men.	9.701700920561294
But his boywomen are the women of a boy.	10.825720161530707
Their life, thought, speech are lent them by males.	9.70864743048147
He chose badly?	13.938980631925935

If others have their will Ann hath a way.	5.99980546722

—As we, or mother Dana, weave and unweave our bodies, Stephen said, from day to day, their molecules shuttled to and fro, so does the artist weave and unweave his image.	8.447074301036032
And as the mole on my right breast is where it was when I was born, though all my body has been woven of new stuff time after time, so through the ghost of the unquiet father the image of the unliving son looks forth.	13.565870721637587
In the intense instant of imagination, when the mind, Shelley says, is a fading coal, that which I was is that which I am and that which in possibility I may come to be.	10.819661007857755
So in the future, the sister of the past, I may see myself as I sit here now but by reflection from that which then I shall be.	13.011730618553011
Drummond of Hawthornden helped you at that stile.	9.142526832783375

_My dearest wife_, Pericles says, _was like this maid._ Will any man love the daughter if he has not loved the mother?	9.02843402367589

Love, yes.	9.118383105128844
Word known to all men.	8.39867018449562
_Amor vero aliquid alicui bonum vult unde et ea quae concupiscimus ..._ —His own image to a man with that queer thing genius is the standard of all experience, material and moral.	8.003256506912276
Such an appeal will touch him.	4.637748368600715

There’s a saying of Goethe’s which Mr Magee likes to quote.	10.061999388587003
