Why does he send to one who is a _buonaroba,_ a bay where all men ride, a maid of honour with a scandalous girlhood, a lordling to woo for him?	10.554331390445633
He was himself a lord of language and had made himself a coistrel gentleman and he had written _Romeo and Juliet_.	12.912648682801443
Why?	12.512270304170855
Belief in himself has been untimely killed.	12.11302246111917
He was overborne in a cornfield first (ryefield, I should say) and he will never be a victor in his own eyes after nor play victoriously the game of laugh and lie down.	10.146759382545211
Assumed dongiovannism will not save him.	5.6545790692563624
No later undoing will undo the first undoing.	10.004836659549186
The tusk of the boar has wounded him there where love lies ableeding.	10.390193021322572
If the shrew is worsted yet there remains to her woman’s invisible weapon.	11.447215926339192
There is, I feel in the words, some goad of the flesh driving him into a new passion, a darker shadow of the first, darkening even his own understanding of himself.	12.95524913898555
A like fate awaits him and the two rages commingle in a whirlpool.	11.976830844765848
They list.	10.570797566163494
And in the porches of their ears I pour.	17.488441620844938
—The soul has been before stricken mortally, a poison poured in the porch of a sleeping ear.	15.395941682595923
But those who are done to death in sleep cannot know the manner of their quell unless their Creator endow their souls with that knowledge in the life to come.	10.036170191591342
The poisoning and the beast with two backs that urged it King Hamlet’s ghost could not know of were he not endowed with knowledge by his creator.	10.797787041216406
That is why the speech (his lean unlovely English) is always turned elsewhere, backward.	8.244578188962109
Ravisher and ravished, what he would but would not, go with him from Lucrece’s bluecircled ivory globes to Imogen’s breast, bare, with its mole cinquespotted.	12.197271825254902
He goes back, weary of the creation he has piled up to hide him from himself, an old dog licking an old sore.	16.27718184429822
But, because loss is his gain, he passes on towards eternity in undiminished personality, untaught by the wisdom he has written or by the laws he has revealed.	12.919177317106787
His beaver is up.	4.729155339580574

He Who Himself begot middler the Holy Ghost and Himself sent Himself, Agenbuyer, between Himself and others, Who, put upon by His fiends, stripped and whipped, was nailed like bat to barndoor, starved on crosstree, Who let Him bury, stood up, harrowed hell, fared into heaven and there these nineteen hundred years sitteth on the right hand of His Own Self but yet shall come in the latter day to doom the quick and dead when all the quick shall be dead already.	7.074751830700666

—Antiquity mentions that Stagyrite schoolurchin and bald heathen sage, Stephen said, who when dying in exile frees and endows his slaves, pays tribute to his elders, wills to be laid in earth near the bones of his dead wife and bids his friends be kind to an old mistress (don’t forget Nell Gwynn Herpyllis) and let her live in his villa.	8.661049968788053

He drew Shylock out of his own long pocket.	10.873620402043963
The son of a maltjobber and moneylender he was himself a cornjobber and moneylender, with ten tods of corn hoarded in the famine riots.	11.129175071435062
His borrowers are no doubt those divers of worship mentioned by Chettle Falstaff who reported his uprightness of dealing.	5.599947340335084
He sued a fellowplayer for the price of a few bags of malt and exacted his pound of flesh in interest for every money lent.	8.283235223218346
How else could Aubrey’s ostler and callboy get rich quick?	11.214751589072518
All events brought grist to his mill.	11.458019966898075
Shylock chimes with the jewbaiting that followed the hanging and quartering of the queen’s leech Lopez, his jew’s heart being plucked forth while the sheeny was yet alive: _Hamlet_ and _Macbeth_ with the coming to the throne of a Scotch philosophaster with a turn for witchroasting.	11.647935409378835

When Rutlandbaconsouthamptonshakespeare or another poet of the same name in the comedy of errors wrote _Hamlet_ he was not the father of his own son merely but, being no more a son, he was and felt himself the father of all his race, the father of his own grandfather, the father of his unborn grandson who, by the same token, never was born, for nature, as Mr Magee understands her, abhors perfection.	12.915861696302857

Age has not withered it.	5.371481458889037

The playwright who wrote the folio of this world and wrote it badly (He gave us light first and the sun two days later), the lord of things as they are whom the most Roman of catholics call _dio boia_, hangman god, is doubtless all in all in all of us, ostler and butcher, and would be bawd and cuckold too but that in the economy of heaven, foretold by Hamlet, there are no more marriages, glorified man, an androgynous angel, being a wife unto himself.	10.13154316566462

He thought, but not for long, of soldiers and sailors, whose legs had been shot off by cannonballs, ending their days in some pauper ward, and of cardinal Wolsey’s words: _If I had served my God as I have served my king He would not have abandoned me in my old days._ He walked by the treeshade of sunnywinking leaves: and towards him came the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P. —Very well, indeed, father.	11.29821528866181

At Newcomen bridge Father Conmee stepped into an outward bound tram for he disliked to traverse on foot the dingy way past Mud Island.	8.046645479938299
Father Conmee sat in a corner of the tramcar, a blue ticket tucked with care in the eye of one plump kid glove, while four shillings, a sixpence and five pennies chuted from his other plump glovepalm into his purse.	12.901101395552864
Passing the ivy church he reflected that the ticket inspector usually made his visit when one had carelessly thrown away the ticket.	7.539624003816339

It was a peaceful day.	12.1759642300156

At Annesley bridge the tram halted and, when it was about to go, an old woman rose suddenly from her place to alight.	11.92511160675192
The conductor pulled the bellstrap to stay the car for her.	5.3222193551755925
She passed out with her basket and a marketnet: and Father Conmee saw the conductor help her and net and basket down: and Father Conmee thought that, as she had nearly passed the end of the penny fare, she was one of those good souls who had always to be told twice _bless you, my child,_ that they have been absolved, _pray for me._ But they had so many worries in life, so many cares, poor creatures.	13.581223105412711
From the hoardings Mr Eugene Stratton grimaced with thick niggerlips at Father Conmee.	7.305368638463477
Father Conmee thought of the souls of black and brown and yellow men and of his sermon on saint Peter Claver S.	9.344902446557057
and the African mission and of the propagation of the faith and of the millions of black and brown and yellow souls that had not received the baptism of water when their last hour came like a thief in the night.	12.335930685964934
That book by the Belgian jesuit, _Le Nombre des Élus,_ seemed to Father Conmee a reasonable plea.	8.509805513953514
Those were millions of human souls created by God in His Own likeness to whom the faith had not (D.V.) been brought.	9.667203137942844
But they were God’s souls, created by God.	12.037900180350753
It seemed to Father Conmee a pity that they should all be lost, a waste, if one might say.	9.85032352785748

Lord Talbot de Malahide, immediate hereditary lord admiral of Malahide and the seas adjoining.	7.423805710127828

Father Conmee, walking, thought of his little book _Old Times in the Barony_ and of the book that might be written about jesuit houses and of Mary Rochfort, daughter of lord Molesworth, first countess of Belvedere.	10.957840257079438
A listless lady, no more young, walked alone the shore of lough Ennel, Mary, first countess of Belvedere, listlessly walking in the evening, not startled when an otter plunged.	8.008591789826989
Who could know the truth?	15.856060743279428

Father Conmee thought of that tyrannous incontinence, needed however for man’s race on earth, and of the ways of God which were not our ways.	10.761745943653123
Don John Conmee walked and moved in times of yore.	10.172114619283978
He was humane and honoured there.	6.986017045352669
He bore in mind secrets confessed and he smiled at smiling noble faces in a beeswaxed drawingroom, ceiled with full fruit clusters.	7.933391218260095
And the hands of a bride and of a bridegroom, noble to noble, were impalmed by Don John Conmee.	10.917095982434757
It was a charming day.	12.86256571056234
The lychgate of a field showed Father Conmee breadths of cabbages, curtseying to him with ample underleaves.	10.057971570056582
The sky showed him a flock of small white clouds going slowly down the wind.	8.64784172529762
_Moutonner,_ the French said.	5.133464296943204
A just and homely word.	6.123661089863144
Father Conmee, reading his office, watched a flock of muttoning clouds over Rathcoffey.	7.312616273947197
His thinsocked ankles were tickled by the stubble of Clongowes field.	7.652423785334414
He walked there, reading in the evening, and heard the cries of the boys’ lines at their play, young cries in the quiet evening.	14.72197624706988
He was their rector: his reign was mild.	10.525532277729898

An ivory bookmark told him the page.	9.010993259624525
Nones.	32.172570290454246
He should have read that before lunch.	13.074558843843072

_Deus in adiutorium._ He walked calmly and read mutely the nones, walking and reading till he came to _Res_ in _Beati immaculati: Principium verborum tuorum veritas: in eternum omnia iudicia iustitiæ tuæ._ A flushed young man came from a gap of a hedge and after him came a young woman with wild nodding daisies in her hand.	7.995128919446734
The young man raised his cap abruptly: the young woman abruptly bent and with slow care detached from her light skirt a clinging twig.	11.087313687087173
Father Conmee blessed both gravely and turned a thin page of his breviary.	13.281932894830362
_Sin: Principes persecuti sunt me gratis: et a verbis tuis formidavit cor meum._ * * * Corny Kelleher closed his long daybook and glanced with his drooping eye at a pine coffinlid sentried in a corner.	7.398060887663467
He pulled himself erect, went to it and, spinning it on its axle, viewed its shape and brass furnishings.	9.101726706464348
Chewing his blade of hay he laid the coffinlid by and came to the doorway.	8.524138490948713
There he tilted his hatbrim to give shade to his eyes and leaned against the doorcase, looking idly out.	9.694116476862213
Corny Kelleher locked his largefooted boots and gazed, his hat downtilted, chewing his blade of hay.	8.971244957494358
Constable 57C, on his beat, stood to pass the time of day.	8.098860970468541

he asked.	5.571194519539272

Every jolt the bloody car gave I had her bumping up against me.	6.924451412430353
Hell’s delights! She has a fine pair, God bless her.	12.487116292638433
Like that.	4.998933309707568
He held his caved hands a cubit from him, frowning: —I was tucking the rug under her and settling her boa all the time.	8.645049540239587
Know what I mean?	13.998839631576264
His hands moulded ample curves of air.	7.099674660771912
He shut his eyes tight in delight, his body shrinking, and blew a sweet chirp from his lips.	11.937482337746316
—The lad stood to attention anyhow, he said with a sigh.	13.231932627611547
Bloom was pointing out all the stars and the comets in the heavens to Chris Callinan and the jarvey: the great bear and Hercules and the dragon, and the whole jingbang lot.	14.391871189561858
But, by God, I was lost, so to speak, in the milky way.	11.709389497354971
He knows them all, faith.	11.352852473523876
At last she spotted a weeny weeshy one miles away.	5.0086051585427125
_And what star is that, Poldy?_ says she.	9.720677459677423
By God, she had Bloom cornered.	13.93532490815529
_That one, is it?_ says Chris Callinan, _sure that’s only what you might call a pinprick._ By God, he wasn’t far wide of the mark.	12.569652845560219
Lenehan stopped and leaned on the riverwall, panting with soft laughter.	8.841134916148711
—I’m weak, he gasped.	21.388855804842592
M’Coy’s white face smiled about it at instants and grew grave.	10.707176173999175
Lenehan walked on again.	6.6855970071524515
He lifted his yachtingcap and scratched his hindhead rapidly.	6.915160912085003
He glanced sideways in the sunlight at M’Coy.	11.313128729595853
—He’s a cultured allroundman, Bloom is, he said seriously.	12.993412622612702
He’s not one of your common or garden...	7.382829149958516
you know...	2.7340362385993706
There’s a touch of the artist about old Bloom.	10.917117851026973
* * * Mr Bloom turned over idly pages of _The Awful Disclosures of Maria Monk_, then of Aristotle’s _Masterpiece._ Crooked botched print.	8.610053284113569
Plates: infants cuddled in a ball in bloodred wombs like livers of slaughtered cows.	6.716214689432378
Lots of them like that at this moment all over the world.	10.963516974232974
All butting with their skulls to get out of it.	7.3234195845710035
Child born every minute somewhere.	7.3074238797115525
Mrs Purefoy.	10.175459993809895
He laid both books aside and glanced at the third: _Tales of the Ghetto_ by Leopold von Sacher Masoch.	10.573343584312465
—That I had, he said, pushing it by.	9.459251693895002
The shopman let two volumes fall on the counter.	8.645755705416427
—Them are two good ones, he said.	4.488450483384812
Onions of his breath came across the counter out of his ruined mouth.	14.83188274321689
He bent to make a bundle of the other books, hugged them against his unbuttoned waistcoat and bore them off behind the dingy curtain.	10.210773223142244
On O’Connell bridge many persons observed the grave deportment and gay apparel of Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c.	7.562869507388551
Mr Bloom, alone, looked at the titles.	18.222970934888654
_Fair Tyrants_ by James Lovebirch.	9.657028365649833
Know the kind that is.	6.181039075157057
Had it?	6.470732668478746
He opened it.	4.292361584289976
Thought so.	7.001174124681293
A woman’s voice behind the dingy curtain.	13.512678815887938
Listen: the man.	8.522057025788762
No: she wouldn’t like that much.	13.393170540782652
Got her it once.	7.345525529775507

More in her line.	14.379816156363566

Here.	12.056869439375285

Mr Bloom read again: _The beautiful woman._ Warmth showered gently over him, cowing his flesh.	8.882725408968332
Flesh yielded amply amid rumpled clothes: whites of eyes swooning up.	4.150257319567517
His nostrils arched themselves for prey.	7.27459621509224

An elderly female, no more young, left the building of the courts of chancery, king’s bench, exchequer and common pleas, having heard in the lord chancellor’s court the case in lunacy of Potterton, in the admiralty division the summons, exparte motion, of the owners of the Lady Cairns versus the owners of the barque Mona, in the court of appeal reservation of judgment in the case of Harvey versus the Ocean Accident and Guarantee Corporation.	8.552856185267247
Phlegmy coughs shook the air of the bookshop, bulging out the dingy curtains.	10.769318639010493
The shopman’s uncombed grey head came out and his unshaven reddened face, coughing.	13.596144888099245
He raked his throat rudely, puked phlegm on the floor.	6.93662031299652
He put his boot on what he had spat, wiping his sole along it, and bent, showing a rawskinned crown, scantily haired.	9.123777703676396
Mr Bloom beheld it.	9.33092623114116
Mastering his troubled breath, he said: —I’ll take this one.	8.395585349347474
The shopman lifted eyes bleared with old rheum.	8.57812551496663
That’s a good one.	9.220772289763714

Mr Dedalus said.	3.7898625602284635

Mr Dedalus asked, his tongue in his cheek.	19.767673834700233

Dilly said.	3.3050219522328192

—What are you doing?	22.284060068582363
Stephen said.	3.3990640623497015
A Stuart face of nonesuch Charles, lank locks falling at its sides.	6.535967908734378
It glowed as she crouched feeding the fire with broken boots.	7.443610110194171
I told her of Paris.	8.938682194276447
Late lieabed under a quilt of old overcoats, fingering a pinchbeck bracelet, Dan Kelly’s token.	8.528445970642123
_Nebrakada femininum._ —What have you there?	14.45285465578889
Stephen asked.	5.479503230507703
—I bought it from the other cart for a penny, Dilly said, laughing nervously.	17.098515612044903
Is it any good?	18.05641379157422
My eyes they say she has.	12.664017281753068
Do others see me so?	10.944000877885989
Quick, far and daring.	11.872786885522066
Shadow of my mind.	11.77289235334425

Chardenal’s French primer.	19.444811994786818
—What did you buy that for?	18.253913003941783
he asked.	5.571194519539272
To learn French?	17.51059908133912
She nodded, reddening and closing tight her lips.	5.136191082327306
Show no surprise.	8.586415177084804
Quite natural.	11.505338535912102
It’s all right.	7.745559458195826
Mind Maggy doesn’t pawn it on you.	8.096314842296897
I suppose all my books are gone.	9.287986318317493
—Some, Dilly said.	3.7920969967720364
We had to.	6.450657948660857
She is drowning.	17.238921403782633
Agenbite.	25.535385961793953
Save her.	4.892668042093682
Agenbite.	25.535385961793953
She will drown me with her, eyes and hair.	9.146295786035681

We. Agenbite of inwit.	8.152640037726922

Misery! Misery! * * * —Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said.	5.725131371549508
How are things?	15.307806929821108
—Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping.	10.828357499569488
Father Cowley brushed his moustache often downward with a scooping hand.	8.87137103234035
Mr Dedalus said.	3.7898625602284635
—Why then not much, Father Cowley said.	6.313986844459234
I’m barricaded up, Simon, with two men prowling around the house trying to effect an entrance.	15.653181441045573
—Jolly, Mr Dedalus said.	4.228090955866448
Who is it?	8.452407460679394
—O, Father Cowley said.	6.193533617551128
A certain gombeen man of our acquaintance.	13.718088020901794
—With a broken back, is it?	10.08490667478028
—The same, Simon, Father Cowley answered.	11.791883897326262
Reuben of that ilk.	19.287099108322927
I’m just waiting for Ben Dollard.	12.330715783093487
He’s going to say a word to long John to get him to take those two men off.	12.693989118299607
All I want is a little time.	11.534086038932461
He looked with vague hope up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in his neck.	11.437311297554674
—I know, Mr Dedalus said, nodding.	14.591910711340986
Poor old bockedy Ben! He’s always doing a good turn for someone.	11.718449928199577
Hold hard! He put on his glasses and gazed towards the metal bridge an instant.	13.138743460272986
Ben Dollard’s loose blue cutaway and square hat above large slops crossed the quay in full gait from the metal bridge.	8.027614705515749
He came towards them at an amble, scratching actively behind his coattails.	10.006348140071127
As he came near Mr Dedalus greeted: —Hold that fellow with the bad trousers.	16.559419098339653
—Hold him now, Ben Dollard said.	6.87915428765584
Mr Dedalus eyed with cold wandering scorn various points of Ben Dollard’s figure.	10.974595214446609
Then, turning to Father Cowley with a nod, he muttered sneeringly: —That’s a pretty garment, isn’t it, for a summer’s day?	14.304618723428842
—Why, God eternally curse your soul, Ben Dollard growled furiously, I threw out more clothes in my time than you ever saw.	10.4770480850061
He stood beside them beaming, on them first and on his roomy clothes from points of which Mr Dedalus flicked fluff, saying: —They were made for a man in his health, Ben, anyhow.	13.355325565461126
—Bad luck to the jewman that made them, Ben Dollard said.	9.146229198934302
Thanks be to God he’s not paid yet.	10.0958064685028
—And how is that _basso profondo_, Benjamin?	15.205339768175737
Father Cowley asked.	8.866087311155422
Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, murmuring, glassyeyed, strode past the Kildare street club.	6.519804879086675
Ben Dollard frowned and, making suddenly a chanter’s mouth, gave forth a deep note.	12.207508507344393
—Aw! he said.	3.6706390910234306
—That’s the style, Mr Dedalus said, nodding to its drone.	11.297657009550974
—What about that?	12.661432148287284
Ben Dollard said.	4.298208717799206
Not too dusty?	16.239760990182177
He turned to both.	12.27234565575195
—That’ll do, Father Cowley said, nodding also.	13.9263832676551
The reverend Hugh C.	6.019247447289253
Love walked from the old chapterhouse of saint Mary’s abbey past James and Charles Kennedy’s, rectifiers, attended by Geraldines tall and personable, towards the Tholsel beyond the ford of hurdles.	8.181064839023428

Come along.	11.04908873456675

Wait awhile...	2.5900596967231486
We’re on the right lay, Bob, believe you me.	9.437117055925466
—For a few days tell him, Father Cowley said anxiously.	14.340115419811692

—What few days?	25.881586859494337
he boomed.	14.949365283168918

Love is the name?	14.141156626180921

* * * —The youngster will be all right, Martin Cunningham said, as they passed out of the Castleyard gate.	13.378533051825608
The policeman touched his forehead.	8.72499445238643

I wrote to Father Conmee and laid the whole case before him.	7.849087004469539

Martin Cunningham said shortly.	15.328118275080994

John Wyse Nolan opened wide eyes.	7.4488253396762785

—Righto, Martin Cunningham said.	3.869746455866199

John Wyse Nolan fell back with Mr Power, while Martin Cunningham took the elbow of a dapper little man in a shower of hail suit, who walked uncertainly, with hasty steps past Micky Anderson’s watches.	12.980042599003369

The empty castle car fronted them at rest in Essex gate.	7.1327696443708035
Martin Cunningham, speaking always, showed often the list at which Jimmy Henry did not glance.	8.856600361653806
—And long John Fanning is here too, John Wyse Nolan said, as large as life.	11.237266386158915

Long John Fanning made no way for them.	6.897530961247948
He removed his large Henry Clay decisively and his large fierce eyes scowled intelligently over all their faces.	9.15336177674726
—Are the conscript fathers pursuing their peaceful deliberations?	6.710337149007513
he said with rich acrid utterance to the assistant town clerk.	12.749852428542336

Where was the marshal, he wanted to know, to keep order in the council chamber.	19.361545896083573
And old Barlow the macebearer laid up with asthma, no mace on the table, nothing in order, no quorum even, and Hutchinson, the lord mayor, in Llandudno and little Lorcan Sherlock doing _locum tenens_ for him.	9.289627321585254
Damned Irish language, language of our forefathers.	11.118569699167521
Long John Fanning blew a plume of smoke from his lips.	8.695063095907534

—What Dignam was that?	11.902921180211825
long John Fanning asked.	7.3634101755493475

—O, my corns! he said plaintively.	18.73581801816474
Come upstairs for goodness’ sake till I sit down somewhere.	8.932817920833992

* * * As they trod across the thick carpet Buck Mulligan whispered behind his Panama to Haines: —Parnell’s brother.	12.278046180003024
There in the corner.	12.081619765043447
They chose a small table near the window, opposite a longfaced man whose beard and gaze hung intently down on a chessboard.	8.038636528259428
—Is that he?	11.751206606064605
Haines asked, twisting round in his seat.	13.902716496533708
—Yes, Mulligan said.	6.368158110443711
That’s John Howard, his brother, our city marshal.	14.894275014526311
John Howard Parnell translated a white bishop quietly and his grey claw went up again to his forehead whereat it rested.	10.765508941102828
An instant after, under its screen, his eyes looked quickly, ghostbright, at his foe and fell once more upon a working corner.	10.32790979535126
—I’ll take a _mélange,_ Haines said to the waitress.	16.46245676581752
—Two _mélanges,_ Buck Mulligan said.	6.234865667338819
And bring us some scones and butter and some cakes as well.	7.857712099061675
When she had gone he said, laughing: —We call it D.B.C. because they have damn bad cakes.	17.774998173658688
O, but you missed Dedalus on _Hamlet._ Haines opened his newbought book.	8.452107189444952
—I’m sorry, he said.	6.21539237551087
Shakespeare is the happy huntingground of all minds that have lost their balance.	12.97330607823886
The onelegged sailor growled at the area of 14 Nelson street: —_England expects_...	8.280953909200942
Buck Mulligan’s primrose waistcoat shook gaily to his laughter.	13.475367277142777
—You should see him, he said, when his body loses its balance.	12.174198795680578
Wandering Ængus I call him.	4.639953892933923
Now I am speculating what it would be likely to be.	13.562182659712809
Such persons always have.	5.992526833409671
Buck Mulligan bent across the table gravely.	18.112993076812064
—They drove his wits astray, he said, by visions of hell.	10.59925147838767
He will never capture the Attic note.	7.911711084854646
The note of Swinburne, of all poets, the white death and the ruddy birth.	12.226055760475981
That is his tragedy.	18.825795899721662
He can never be a poet.	14.699904158397086
The joy of creation...	3.1464986189278052
—Eternal punishment, Haines said, nodding curtly.	9.781705344409065
I see.	5.865550534154977
I tackled him this morning on belief.	9.861517263440025
There was something on his mind, I saw.	16.831457357137165
It’s rather interesting because professor Pokorny of Vienna makes an interesting point out of that.	7.235641034274625
Buck Mulligan’s watchful eyes saw the waitress come.	12.11367745457326
He helped her to unload her tray.	8.897665671273568
—He can find no trace of hell in ancient Irish myth, Haines said, amid the cheerful cups.	9.860177818927339
The moral idea seems lacking, the sense of destiny, of retribution.	11.243677975937056
Rather strange he should have just that fixed idea.	8.99581214948908
Does he write anything for your movement?	14.831729333328532
He sank two lumps of sugar deftly longwise through the whipped cream.	8.318690780067467
Buck Mulligan slit a steaming scone in two and plastered butter over its smoking pith.	8.301365015922734
He bit off a soft piece hungrily.	13.466062517537727
—Ten years, he said, chewing and laughing.	9.720827270099464
He is going to write something in ten years.	13.317303638672401
—Seems a long way off, Haines said, thoughtfully lifting his spoon.	11.837016548383005
Still, I shouldn’t wonder if he did after all.	14.484645944113836
He tasted a spoonful from the creamy cone of his cup.	11.203141493290923
—This is real Irish cream I take it, he said with forbearance.	11.207576607213678
I don’t want to be imposed on.	10.855391202591504
Elijah, skiff, light crumpled throwaway, sailed eastward by flanks of ships and trawlers, amid an archipelago of corks, beyond new Wapping street past Benson’s ferry, and by the threemasted schooner _Rosevean_ from Bridgwater with bricks.	6.752043842436826
* * * Almidano Artifoni walked past Holles street, past Sewell’s yard.	12.381119584785537
Distantly behind him a blind stripling tapped his way by the wall of College park.	11.902475012951015
Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell walked as far as Mr Lewis Werner’s cheerful windows, then turned and strode back along Merrion square, his stickumbrelladustcoat dangling.	9.990123424665661
At the corner of Wilde’s house he halted, frowned at Elijah’s name announced on the Metropolitan hall, frowned at the distant pleasance of duke’s lawn.	14.005609037294752
His eyeglass flashed frowning in the sun.	7.675266048243168
With ratsteeth bared he muttered: —_Coactus volui._ He strode on for Clare street, grinding his fierce word.	9.13762327559161
As he strode past Mr Bloom’s dental windows the sway of his dustcoat brushed rudely from its angle a slender tapping cane and swept onwards, having buffeted a thewless body.	8.474569566382973
The blind stripling turned his sickly face after the striding form.	8.724013185642178
—God’s curse on you, he said sourly, whoever you are! You’re blinder nor I am, you bitch’s bastard! * * * Opposite Ruggy O’Donohoe’s Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam, pawing the pound and a half of Mangan’s, late Fehrenbach’s, porksteaks he had been sent for, went along warm Wicklow street dawdling.	11.0487207450759
It was too blooming dull sitting in the parlour with Mrs Stoer and Mrs Quigley and Mrs MacDowell and the blind down and they all at their sniffles and sipping sups of the superior tawny sherry uncle Barney brought from Tunney’s.	10.385744171625896
And they eating crumbs of the cottage fruitcake, jawing the whole blooming time and sighing.	10.277500484676752
After Wicklow lane the window of Madame Doyle, courtdress milliner, stopped him.	4.971157907169659
He stood looking in at the two puckers stripped to their pelts and putting up their props.	12.843122237284458
From the sidemirrors two mourning Masters Dignam gaped silently.	7.585482181551892
Myler Keogh, Dublin’s pet lamb, will meet sergeantmajor Bennett, the Portobello bruiser, for a purse of fifty sovereigns.	10.356352318055519
Gob, that’d be a good pucking match to see.	11.922719262569151
Myler Keogh, that’s the chap sparring out to him with the green sash.	12.897150529211729
I could easy do a bunk on ma.	12.363678779814958
Master Dignam on his left turned as he turned.	15.351363879941886
That’s me in mourning.	13.673011789922947
When is it?	7.046730049903726
May the twentysecond.	14.405000776322408
Sure, the blooming thing is all over.	12.00577121462433
He turned to the right and on his right Master Dignam turned, his cap awry, his collar sticking up.	13.233171480903996
Buttoning it down, his chin lifted, he saw the image of Marie Kendall, charming soubrette, beside the two puckers.	11.40596057581255
One of them mots that do be in the packets of fags Stoer smokes that his old fellow welted hell out of him for one time he found out.	10.979250652128762
Master Dignam got his collar down and dawdled on.	8.431891445464569
The best pucker going for strength was Fitzsimons.	9.542004209382386
One puck in the wind from that fellow would knock you into the middle of next week, man.	9.915305339188118
But the best pucker for science was Jem Corbet before Fitzsimons knocked the stuffings out of him, dodging and all.	7.114863065546896
In Grafton street Master Dignam saw a red flower in a toff’s mouth and a swell pair of kicks on him and he listening to what the drunk was telling him and grinning all the time.	12.774118671063006
No Sandymount tram.	8.211195623572625
Master Dignam walked along Nassau street, shifted the porksteaks to his other hand.	8.110494837516693
His collar sprang up again and he tugged it down.	9.39264714751212
The blooming stud was too small for the buttonhole of the shirt, blooming end to it.	8.478583683630317
He met schoolboys with satchels.	9.587790448349816
I’m not going tomorrow either, stay away till Monday.	11.126128681004635
He met other schoolboys.	10.034884035775905
Do they notice I’m in mourning?	12.432981844657812
Uncle Barney said he’d get it into the paper tonight.	13.731088010795041
Then they’ll all see it in the paper and read my name printed and pa’s name.	12.114187613637474
His face got all grey instead of being red like it was and there was a fly walking over it up to his eye.	10.99599002383863
The scrunch that was when they were screwing the screws into the coffin: and the bumps when they were bringing it downstairs.	12.806218312864871
Pa was inside it and ma crying in the parlour and uncle Barney telling the men how to get it round the bend.	12.032493372525234
A big coffin it was, and high and heavylooking.	10.47137877017521
How was that?	9.637384668838278
The last night pa was boosed he was standing on the landing there bawling out for his boots to go out to Tunney’s for to boose more and he looked butty and short in his shirt.	12.997886419131618
Never see him again.	8.581341273696479
Death, that is.	6.42953874276644
Pa is dead.	6.609452982428036
My father is dead.	7.946770679755921
He told me to be a good son to ma.	14.178055308965835
I couldn’t hear the other things he said but I saw his tongue and his teeth trying to say it better.	16.74168314748025
Poor pa.	11.42439294706638
That was Mr Dignam, my father.	13.13754113736838
I hope he’s in purgatory now because he went to confession to Father Conroy on Saturday night.	9.441028174259802

The viceroy was most cordially greeted on his way through the metropolis.	13.091795247181494

In the porch of Four Courts Richie Goulding with the costbag of Goulding, Collis and Ward saw him with surprise.	10.111869962918373
Past Richmond bridge at the doorstep of the office of Reuben J Dodd, solicitor, agent for the Patriotic Insurance Company, an elderly female about to enter changed her plan and retracing her steps by King’s windows smiled credulously on the representative of His Majesty.	9.968686423536331

Geraghty, esquire, of 29 Arbour hill in the city of Dublin, Arran quay ward, gentleman, hereinafter called the purchaser, videlicet, five pounds avoirdupois of first choice tea at three shillings and no pence per pound avoirdupois and three stone avoirdupois of sugar, crushed crystal, at threepence per pound avoirdupois, the said purchaser debtor to the said vendor of one pound five shillings and sixpence sterling for value received which amount shall be paid by said purchaser to said vendor in weekly instalments every seven calendar days of three shillings and no pence sterling: and the said nonperishable goods shall not be pawned or pledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said purchaser but shall be and remain and be held to be the sole and exclusive property of the said vendor to be disposed of at his good will and pleasure until the said amount shall have been duly paid by the said purchaser to the said vendor in the manner herein set forth as this day hereby agreed between the said vendor, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the one part and the said purchaser, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the other part.	8.043128451593947

In Inisfail the fair there lies a land, the land of holy Michan.	10.279341604576958
There rises a watchtower beheld of men afar.	7.6096487074864365

In the mild breezes of the west and of the east the lofty trees wave in different directions their firstclass foliage, the wafty sycamore, the Lebanonian cedar, the exalted planetree, the eugenic eucalyptus and other ornaments of the arboreal world with which that region is thoroughly well supplied.	11.396611082500948
Lovely maidens sit in close proximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs while they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden ingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings, creels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects.	7.108591070605308
And heroes voyage from afar to woo them, from Eblana to Slievemargy, the peerless princes of unfettered Munster and of Connacht the just and of smooth sleek Leinster and of Cruachan’s land and of Armagh the splendid and of the noble district of Boyle, princes, the sons of kings.	9.273186298023676
And there rises a shining palace whose crystal glittering roof is seen by mariners who traverse the extensive sea in barks built expressly for that purpose, and thither come all herds and fatlings and firstfruits of that land for O’Connell Fitzsimon takes toll of them, a chieftain descended from chieftains.	7.534637092454166
Thither the extremely large wains bring foison of the fields, flaskets of cauliflowers, floats of spinach, pineapple chunks, Rangoon beans, strikes of tomatoes, drums of figs, drills of Swedes, spherical potatoes and tallies of iridescent kale, York and Savoy, and trays of onions, pearls of the earth, and punnets of mushrooms and custard marrows and fat vetches and bere and rape and red green yellow brown russet sweet big bitter ripe pomellated apples and chips of strawberries and sieves of gooseberries, pulpy and pelurious, and strawberries fit for princes and raspberries from their canes.	5.069071624212229

The widewinged nostrils, from which bristles of the same tawny hue projected, were of such capaciousness that within their cavernous obscurity the fieldlark might easily have lodged her nest.	7.914418686750848
The eyes in which a tear and a smile strove ever for the mastery were of the dimensions of a goodsized cauliflower.	16.232427723691554
A powerful current of warm breath issued at regular intervals from the profound cavity of his mouth while in rhythmic resonance the loud strong hale reverberations of his formidable heart thundered rumblingly causing the ground, the summit of the lofty tower and the still loftier walls of the cave to vibrate and tremble.	9.598693647897436
He wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching to the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by a girdle of plaited straw and rushes.	9.335664934337641

Questioned by his earthname as to his whereabouts in the heavenworld he stated that he was now on the path of prālāyā or return but was still submitted to trial at the hands of certain bloodthirsty entities on the lower astral levels.	11.486117941547993
In reply to a question as to his first sensations in the great divide beyond he stated that previously he had seen as in a glass darkly but that those who had passed over had summit possibilities of atmic development opened up to them.	11.882636248341027
Interrogated as to whether life there resembled our experience in the flesh he stated that he had heard from more favoured beings now in the spirit that their abodes were equipped with every modern home comfort such as tālāfānā, ālāvātār, hātākāldā, wātāklāsāt and that the highest adepts were steeped in waves of volupcy of the very purest nature.	8.090256289968512

So they started talking about capital punishment and of course Bloom comes out with the why and the wherefore and all the codology of the business and the old dog smelling him all the time I’m told those jewies does have a sort of a queer odour coming off them for dogs about I don’t know what all deterrent effect and so forth and so on.	10.766003202437364

The distinguished scientist Herr Professor Luitpold Blumenduft tendered medical evidence to the effect that the instantaneous fracture of the cervical vertebrae and consequent scission of the spinal cord would, according to the best approved tradition of medical science, be calculated to inevitably produce in the human subject a violent ganglionic stimulus of the nerve centres of the genital apparatus, thereby causing the elastic pores of the _corpora cavernosa_ to rapidly dilate in such a way as to instantaneously facilitate the flow of blood to that part of the human anatomy known as the penis or male organ resulting in the phenomenon which has been denominated by the faculty a morbid upwards and outwards philoprogenitive erection _in articulo mortis per diminutionem capitis._ So of course the citizen was only waiting for the wink of the word and he starts gassing out of him about the invincibles and the old guard and the men of sixtyseven and who fears to speak of ninetyeight and Joe with him about all the fellows that were hanged, drawn and transported for the cause by drumhead courtmartial and a new Ireland and new this, that and the other.	9.744673062976602

Time they were stopping up in the _City Arms_ pisser Burke told me there was an old one there with a cracked loodheramaun of a nephew and Bloom trying to get the soft side of her doing the mollycoddle playing bézique to come in for a bit of the wampum in her will and not eating meat of a Friday because the old one was always thumping her craw and taking the lout out for a walk.	13.306910983945647
And one time he led him the rounds of Dublin and, by the holy farmer, he never cried crack till he brought him home as drunk as a boiled owl and he said he did it to teach him the evils of alcohol and by herrings, if the three women didn’t near roast him, it’s a queer story, the old one, Bloom’s wife and Mrs O’Dowd that kept the hotel.	12.328452422369521

The last farewell was affecting in the extreme.	13.053386286426258
From the belfries far and near the funereal deathbell tolled unceasingly while all around the gloomy precincts rolled the ominous warning of a hundred muffled drums punctuated by the hollow booming of pieces of ordnance.	8.960246086516065
The deafening claps of thunder and the dazzling flashes of lightning which lit up the ghastly scene testified that the artillery of heaven had lent its supernatural pomp to the already gruesome spectacle.	7.779544171930661
A torrential rain poured down from the floodgates of the angry heavens upon the bared heads of the assembled multitude which numbered at the lowest computation five hundred thousand persons.	11.50775950540687
A posse of Dublin Metropolitan police superintended by the Chief Commissioner in person maintained order in the vast throng for whom the York street brass and reed band whiled away the intervening time by admirably rendering on their blackdraped instruments the matchless melody endeared to us from the cradle by Speranza’s plaintive muse.	8.11681914595552
Special quick excursion trains and upholstered charabancs had been provided for the comfort of our country cousins of whom there were large contingents.	9.642917903319338
Considerable amusement was caused by the favourite Dublin streetsingers L-n-h-n and M-ll-g-n who sang _The Night before Larry was stretched_ in their usual mirth-provoking fashion.	6.713932654671091
Our two inimitable drolls did a roaring trade with their broadsheets among lovers of the comedy element and nobody who has a corner in his heart for real Irish fun without vulgarity will grudge them their hardearned pennies.	8.378686889689105
The children of the Male and Female Foundling Hospital who thronged the windows overlooking the scene were delighted with this unexpected addition to the day’s entertainment and a word of praise is due to the Little Sisters of the Poor for their excellent idea of affording the poor fatherless and motherless children a genuinely instructive treat.	9.253236918635391
The viceregal houseparty which included many wellknown ladies was chaperoned by Their Excellencies to the most favourable positions on the grandstand while the picturesque foreign delegation known as the Friends of the Emerald Isle was accommodated on a tribune directly opposite.	8.81896986418693
The delegation, present in full force, consisted of Commendatore Bacibaci Beninobenone (the semiparalysed _doyen_ of the party who had to be assisted to his seat by the aid of a powerful steam crane), Monsieur Pierrepaul Petitépatant, the Grandjoker Vladinmire Pokethankertscheff, the Archjoker Leopold Rudolph von Schwanzenbad-Hodenthaler, Countess Marha Virága Kisászony Putrápesthi, Hiram Y.	8.357296256416173
Bomboost, Count Athanatos Karamelopulos, Ali Baba Backsheesh Rahat Lokum Effendi, Señor Hidalgo Caballero Don Pecadillo y Palabras y Paternoster de la Malora de la Malaria, Hokopoko Harakiri, Hi Hung Chang, Olaf Kobberkeddelsen, Mynheer Trik van Trumps, Pan Poleaxe Paddyrisky, Goosepond Prhklstr Kratchinabritchisitch, Borus Hupinkoff, Herr Hurhausdirektorpresident Hans Chuechli-Steuerli, Nationalgymnasiummuseumsanatoriumandsuspensoriumsordinaryprivatdocentge neralhistoryspecialprofessordoctor Kriegfried Ueberallgemein.	3.6439255170186646
All the delegates without exception expressed themselves in the strongest possible heterogeneous terms concerning the nameless barbarity which they had been called upon to witness.	9.547545651185825
An animated altercation (in which all took part) ensued among the F.	7.395533166098636
T.	11.481841078558022
E.	10.594970405422256
I.	7.73347927951542
as to whether the eighth or the ninth of March was the correct date of the birth of Ireland’s patron saint.	13.08912183756031
In the course of the argument cannonballs, scimitars, boomerangs, blunderbusses, stinkpots, meatchoppers, umbrellas, catapults, knuckledusters, sandbags, lumps of pig iron were resorted to and blows were freely exchanged.	5.618875233011048
The baby policeman, Constable MacFadden, summoned by special courier from Booterstown, quickly restored order and with lightning promptitude proposed the seventeenth of the month as a solution equally honourable for both contending parties.	6.356327506828873
The readywitted ninefooter’s suggestion at once appealed to all and was unanimously accepted.	12.917231846411125
Constable MacFadden was heartily congratulated by all the F.	7.626171476706514
T.	11.481841078558022
E.	10.594970405422256
I., several of whom were bleeding profusely.	11.674317282061551
Commendatore Beninobenone having been extricated from underneath the presidential armchair, it was explained by his legal adviser Avvocato Pagamimi that the various articles secreted in his thirtytwo pockets had been abstracted by him during the affray from the pockets of his junior colleagues in the hope of bringing them to their senses.	11.427945588486624
The objects (which included several hundred ladies’ and gentlemen’s gold and silver watches) were promptly restored to their rightful owners and general harmony reigned supreme.	8.064598109842812
Quietly, unassumingly Rumbold stepped on to the scaffold in faultless morning dress and wearing his favourite flower, the _Gladiolus Cruentus_.	8.772311381470919
He announced his presence by that gentle Rumboldian cough which so many have tried (unsuccessfully) to imitate—short, painstaking yet withal so characteristic of the man.	6.261488138109876
The arrival of the worldrenowned headsman was greeted by a roar of acclamation from the huge concourse, the viceregal ladies waving their handkerchiefs in their excitement while the even more excitable foreign delegates cheered vociferously in a medley of cries, _hoch, banzai, eljen, zivio, chinchin, polla kronia, hiphip, vive, Allah_, amid which the ringing _evviva_ of the delegate of the land of song (a high double F recalling those piercingly lovely notes with which the eunuch Catalani beglamoured our greatgreatgrandmothers) was easily distinguishable.	7.407306116411148
It was exactly seventeen o’clock.	10.270891258713501
The signal for prayer was then promptly given by megaphone and in an instant all heads were bared, the commendatore’s patriarchal sombrero, which has been in the possession of his family since the revolution of Rienzi, being removed by his medical adviser in attendance, Dr Pippi.	10.541204153049733
The learned prelate who administered the last comforts of holy religion to the hero martyr when about to pay the death penalty knelt in a most christian spirit in a pool of rainwater, his cassock above his hoary head, and offered up to the throne of grace fervent prayers of supplication.	10.117558992742037
Hard by the block stood the grim figure of the executioner, his visage being concealed in a tengallon pot with two circular perforated apertures through which his eyes glowered furiously.	11.76472307987659
As he awaited the fatal signal he tested the edge of his horrible weapon by honing it upon his brawny forearm or decapitated in rapid succession a flock of sheep which had been provided by the admirers of his fell but necessary office.	7.701060107951247
On a handsome mahogany table near him were neatly arranged the quartering knife, the various finely tempered disembowelling appliances (specially supplied by the worldfamous firm of cutlers, Messrs John Round and Sons, Sheffield), a terra cotta saucepan for the reception of the duodenum, colon, blind intestine and appendix etc when successfully extracted and two commodious milkjugs destined to receive the most precious blood of the most precious victim.	7.6472725070343675
Quite an excellent repast consisting of rashers and eggs, fried steak and onions, done to a nicety, delicious hot breakfast rolls and invigorating tea had been considerately provided by the authorities for the consumption of the central figure of the tragedy who was in capital spirits when prepared for death and evinced the keenest interest in the proceedings from beginning to end but he, with an abnegation rare in these our times, rose nobly to the occasion and expressed the dying wish (immediately acceded to) that the meal should be divided in aliquot parts among the members of the sick and indigent roomkeepers’ association as a token of his regard and esteem.	9.304564061420457
The _nec_ and _non plus ultra_ of emotion were reached when the blushing bride elect burst her way through the serried ranks of the bystanders and flung herself upon the muscular bosom of him who was about to be launched into eternity for her sake.	10.042945988929747
The hero folded her willowy form in a loving embrace murmuring fondly _Sheila, my own_.	8.92633673107825
Encouraged by this use of her christian name she kissed passionately all the various suitable areas of his person which the decencies of prison garb permitted her ardour to reach.	9.990792729390495
She swore to him as they mingled the salt streams of their tears that she would ever cherish his memory, that she would never forget her hero boy who went to his death with a song on his lips as if he were but going to a hurling match in Clonturk park.	11.677744571862926
That monster audience simply rocked with delight.	5.827088517032185
But anon they were overcome with grief and clasped their hands for the last time.	8.541184520364848
A fresh torrent of tears burst from their lachrymal ducts and the vast concourse of people, touched to the inmost core, broke into heartrending sobs, not the least affected being the aged prebendary himself.	7.916589043067504
Big strong men, officers of the peace and genial giants of the royal Irish constabulary, were making frank use of their handkerchiefs and it is safe to say that there was not a dry eye in that record assemblage.	13.278590666430542
A most romantic incident occurred when a handsome young Oxford graduate, noted for his chivalry towards the fair sex, stepped forward and, presenting his visiting card, bankbook and genealogical tree, solicited the hand of the hapless young lady, requesting her to name the day, and was accepted on the spot.	8.310705912197303
Every lady in the audience was presented with a tasteful souvenir of the occasion in the shape of a skull and crossbones brooch, a timely and generous act which evoked a fresh outburst of emotion: and when the gallant young Oxonian (the bearer, by the way, of one of the most timehonoured names in Albion’s history) placed on the finger of his blushing _fiancée_ an expensive engagement ring with emeralds set in the form of a fourleaved shamrock the excitement knew no bounds.	10.398115771382894
Nay, even the stern provostmarshal, lieutenantcolonel Tomkin-Maxwell ffrenchmullan Tomlinson, who presided on the sad occasion, he who had blown a considerable number of sepoys from the cannonmouth without flinching, could not now restrain his natural emotion.	9.132533741529059
With his mailed gauntlet he brushed away a furtive tear and was overheard, by those privileged burghers who happened to be in his immediate _entourage,_ to murmur to himself in a faltering undertone: —God blimey if she aint a clinker, that there bleeding tart.	9.40342181523506
Blimey it makes me kind of bleeding cry, straight, it does, when I sees her cause I thinks of my old mashtub what’s waiting for me down Limehouse way.	10.613777720413724
So then the citizen begins talking about the Irish language and the corporation meeting and all to that and the shoneens that can’t speak their own language and Joe chipping in because he stuck someone for a quid and Bloom putting in his old goo with his twopenny stump that he cadged off of Joe and talking about the Gaelic league and the antitreating league and drink, the curse of Ireland.	12.719686827340905
Antitreating is about the size of it.	6.817333022362518
Gob, he’d let you pour all manner of drink down his throat till the Lord would call him before you’d ever see the froth of his pint.	14.798071509593441
And one night I went in with a fellow into one of their musical evenings, song and dance about she could get up on a truss of hay she could my Maureen Lay and there was a fellow with a Ballyhooly blue ribbon badge spiffing out of him in Irish and a lot of colleen bawns going about with temperance beverages and selling medals and oranges and lemonade and a few old dry buns, gob, flahoolagh entertainment, don’t be talking.	9.458743435101995
Ireland sober is Ireland free.	6.865036232548826
And then an old fellow starts blowing into his bagpipes and all the gougers shuffling their feet to the tune the old cow died of.	11.201034615402916
And one or two sky pilots having an eye around that there was no goings on with the females, hitting below the belt.	9.256586552384434

Such growling you never heard as they let off between them.	8.561488833341963

Growling and grousing and his eye all bloodshot from the drouth is in it and the hydrophobia dropping out of his jaws.	13.263256838417853
All those who are interested in the spread of human culture among the lower animals (and their name is legion) should make a point of not missing the really marvellous exhibition of cynanthropy given by the famous old Irish red setter wolfdog formerly known by the _sobriquet_ of Garryowen and recently rechristened by his large circle of friends and acquaintances Owen Garry.	9.284888303324035
The exhibition, which is the result of years of training by kindness and a carefully thoughtout dietary system, comprises, among other achievements, the recitation of verse.	8.734054620659185
Our greatest living phonetic expert (wild horses shall not drag it from us!) has left no stone unturned in his efforts to delucidate and compare the verse recited and has found it bears a _striking_ resemblance (the italics are ours) to the ranns of ancient Celtic bards.	7.407211818071616
C.	8.56499542248637
points out in an interesting communication published by an evening contemporary) of the harsher and more personal note which is found in the satirical effusions of the famous Raftery and of Donal MacConsidine to say nothing of a more modern lyrist at present very much in the public eye.	11.634374770342903
We subjoin a specimen which has been rendered into English by an eminent scholar whose name for the moment we are not at liberty to disclose though we believe that our readers will find the topical allusion rather more than an indication.	8.559977107076799
The metrical system of the canine original, which recalls the intricate alliterative and isosyllabic rules of the Welsh englyn, is infinitely more complicated but we believe our readers will agree that the spirit has been well caught.	9.297562155682755
Perhaps it should be added that the effect is greatly increased if Owen’s verse be spoken somewhat slowly and indistinctly in a tone suggestive of suppressed rancour.	9.640726431913324
The curse of my curses Seven days every day And seven dry Thursdays On you, Barney Kiernan, Has no sup of water To cool my courage, And my guts red roaring After Lowry’s lights.	7.741142990603913

A most interesting discussion took place in the ancient hall of _Brian O’Ciarnain’s_ in _Sraid na Bretaine Bheag_, under the auspices of _Sluagh na h-Eireann_, on the revival of ancient Gaelic sports and the importance of physical culture, as understood in ancient Greece and ancient Rome and ancient Ireland, for the development of the race.	8.735334154718485
The venerable president of the noble order was in the chair and the attendance was of large dimensions.	13.578838459770951
After an instructive discourse by the chairman, a magnificent oration eloquently and forcibly expressed, a most interesting and instructive discussion of the usual high standard of excellence ensued as to the desirability of the revivability of the ancient games and sports of our ancient Panceltic forefathers.	11.271024284249672
The wellknown and highly respected worker in the cause of our old tongue, Mr Joseph M’Carthy Hynes, made an eloquent appeal for the resuscitation of the ancient Gaelic sports and pastimes, practised morning and evening by Finn MacCool, as calculated to revive the best traditions of manly strength and prowess handed down to us from ancient ages.	8.971571627875168
L.	11.002864267888413
Bloom, who met with a mixed reception of applause and hisses, having espoused the negative the vocalist chairman brought the discussion to a close, in response to repeated requests and hearty plaudits from all parts of a bumper house, by a remarkably noteworthy rendering of the immortal Thomas Osborne Davis’ evergreen verses (happily too familiar to need recalling here) _A nation once again_ in the execution of which the veteran patriot champion may be said without fear of contradiction to have fairly excelled himself.	8.311586761575306
The Irish Caruso-Garibaldi was in superlative form and his stentorian notes were heard to the greatest advantage in the timehonoured anthem sung as only our citizen can sing it.	8.67833285631525
His superb highclass vocalism, which by its superquality greatly enhanced his already international reputation, was vociferously applauded by the large audience among which were to be noticed many prominent members of the clergy as well as representatives of the press and the bar and the other learned professions.	10.620301310516334

It was a historic and a hefty battle when Myler and Percy were scheduled to don the gloves for the purse of fifty sovereigns.	8.089901348443224
Handicapped as he was by lack of poundage, Dublin’s pet lamb made up for it by superlative skill in ringcraft.	10.169676062265673
The final bout of fireworks was a gruelling for both champions.	8.90227873542365
The welterweight sergeantmajor had tapped some lively claret in the previous mixup during which Keogh had been receivergeneral of rights and lefts, the artilleryman putting in some neat work on the pet’s nose, and Myler came on looking groggy.	10.909955474523068
The soldier got to business, leading off with a powerful left jab to which the Irish gladiator retaliated by shooting out a stiff one flush to the point of Bennett’s jaw.	11.877688161314945
The redcoat ducked but the Dubliner lifted him with a left hook, the body punch being a fine one.	9.553134503266092
The men came to handigrips.	14.3596055014324
Myler quickly became busy and got his man under, the bout ending with the bulkier man on the ropes, Myler punishing him.	8.260787266685305
The Englishman, whose right eye was nearly closed, took his corner where he was liberally drenched with water and when the bell went came on gamey and brimful of pluck, confident of knocking out the fistic Eblanite in jigtime.	8.111805509925997
It was a fight to a finish and the best man for it.	12.088309757137088
The two fought like tigers and excitement ran fever high.	5.750408140181197
The referee twice cautioned Pucking Percy for holding but the pet was tricky and his footwork a treat to watch.	6.428762633020177
After a brisk exchange of courtesies during which a smart upper cut of the military man brought blood freely from his opponent’s mouth the lamb suddenly waded in all over his man and landed a terrific left to Battling Bennett’s stomach, flooring him flat.	9.285575279666405
It was a knockout clean and clever.	13.715203224687349
Amid tense expectation the Portobello bruiser was being counted out when Bennett’s second Ole Pfotts Wettstein threw in the towel and the Santry boy was declared victor to the frenzied cheers of the public who broke through the ringropes and fairly mobbed him with delight.	8.746202860765418

And our potteries and textiles, the finest in the whole world! And our wool that was sold in Rome in the time of Juvenal and our flax and our damask from the looms of Antrim and our Limerick lace, our tanneries and our white flint glass down there by Ballybough and our Huguenot poplin that we have since Jacquard de Lyon and our woven silk and our Foxford tweeds and ivory raised point from the Carmelite convent in New Ross, nothing like it in the whole wide world.	9.208539217385056

The fashionable international world attended _en masse_ this afternoon at the wedding of the chevalier Jean Wyse de Neaulan, grand high chief ranger of the Irish National Foresters, with Miss Fir Conifer of Pine Valley.	7.895354607653475
Lady Sylvester Elmshade, Mrs Barbara Lovebirch, Mrs Poll Ash, Mrs Holly Hazeleyes, Miss Daphne Bays, Miss Dorothy Canebrake, Mrs Clyde Twelvetrees, Mrs Rowan Greene, Mrs Helen Vinegadding, Miss Virginia Creeper, Miss Gladys Beech, Miss Olive Garth, Miss Blanche Maple, Mrs Maud Mahogany, Miss Myra Myrtle, Miss Priscilla Elderflower, Miss Bee Honeysuckle, Miss Grace Poplar, Miss O Mimosa San, Miss Rachel Cedarfrond, the Misses Lilian and Viola Lilac, Miss Timidity Aspenall, Mrs Kitty Dewey-Mosse, Miss May Hawthorne, Mrs Gloriana Palme, Mrs Liana Forrest, Mrs Arabella Blackwood and Mrs Norma Holyoake of Oakholme Regis graced the ceremony by their presence.	6.793832857801288
The bride who was given away by her father, the M’Conifer of the Glands, looked exquisitely charming in a creation carried out in green mercerised silk, moulded on an underslip of gloaming grey, sashed with a yoke of broad emerald and finished with a triple flounce of darkerhued fringe, the scheme being relieved by bretelles and hip insertions of acorn bronze.	8.925987564735225
The maids of honour, Miss Larch Conifer and Miss Spruce Conifer, sisters of the bride, wore very becoming costumes in the same tone, a dainty _motif_ of plume rose being worked into the pleats in a pinstripe and repeated capriciously in the jadegreen toques in the form of heron feathers of paletinted coral.	9.16526758658585
Senhor Enrique Flor presided at the organ with his wellknown ability and, in addition to the prescribed numbers of the nuptial mass, played a new and striking arrangement of _Woodman, spare that tree_ at the conclusion of the service.	10.881777912091195
On leaving the church of Saint Fiacre _in Horto_ after the papal blessing the happy pair were subjected to a playful crossfire of hazelnuts, beechmast, bayleaves, catkins of willow, ivytod, hollyberries, mistletoe sprigs and quicken shoots.	5.112507371878675
Mr and Mrs Wyse Conifer Neaulan will spend a quiet honeymoon in the Black Forest.	10.843659488437222

Our harbours that are empty will be full again, Queenstown, Kinsale, Galway, Blacksod Bay, Ventry in the kingdom of Kerry, Killybegs, the third largest harbour in the wide world with a fleet of masts of the Galway Lynches and the Cavan O’Reillys and the O’Kennedys of Dublin when the earl of Desmond could make a treaty with the emperor Charles the Fifth himself.	10.088466844149039

And says John Wyse: —’Tis a custom more honoured in the breach than in the observance.	12.006450640978047
Then he was telling us the master at arms comes along with a long cane and he draws out and he flogs the bloody backside off of the poor lad till he yells meila murder.	14.100887047557261
—That’s your glorious British navy, says the citizen, that bosses the earth.	8.535367473127486
The fellows that never will be slaves, with the only hereditary chamber on the face of God’s earth and their land in the hands of a dozen gamehogs and cottonball barons.	13.485401160391262
That’s the great empire they boast about of drudges and whipped serfs.	8.519148490900157
—On which the sun never rises, says Joe.	9.095613767192354
—And the tragedy of it is, says the citizen, they believe it.	8.755369774291518
The unfortunate yahoos believe it.	3.8681937271829407
They believe in rod, the scourger almighty, creator of hell upon earth, and in Jacky Tar, the son of a gun, who was conceived of unholy boast, born of the fighting navy, suffered under rump and dozen, was scarified, flayed and curried, yelled like bloody hell, the third day he arose again from the bed, steered into haven, sitteth on his beamend till further orders whence he shall come to drudge for a living and be paid.	8.47616813431875
I mean wouldn’t it be the same here if you put force against force?	16.087010787674643
Didn’t I tell you?	9.376706374243875
As true as I’m drinking this porter if he was at his last gasp he’d try to downface you that dying was living.	10.873322285423775
—We’ll put force against force, says the citizen.	7.266265791289203
We have our greater Ireland beyond the sea.	8.23935258034926
They were driven out of house and home in the black 47.	11.992330722833445
Their mudcabins and their shielings by the roadside were laid low by the batteringram and the _Times_ rubbed its hands and told the whitelivered Saxons there would soon be as few Irish in Ireland as redskins in America.	8.137210763947326
Even the Grand Turk sent us his piastres.	9.498497573628326
But the Sassenach tried to starve the nation at home while the land was full of crops that the British hyenas bought and sold in Rio de Janeiro.	9.388433430350874
Ay, they drove out the peasants in hordes.	17.217243000852317
Twenty thousand of them died in the coffinships.	19.158915243210878
But those that came to the land of the free remember the land of bondage.	14.631367199116454
And they will come again and with a vengeance, no cravens, the sons of Granuaile, the champions of Kathleen ni Houlihan.	13.432321432611687
—Perfectly true, says Bloom.	6.3471114715947925
But my point was...	3.490128697875229
Since the poor old woman told us that the French were on the sea and landed at Killala.	14.105397158042793
—Ay, says John Wyse.	9.060265176477294
We fought for the royal Stuarts that reneged us against the Williamites and they betrayed us.	8.88427461291976
Remember Limerick and the broken treatystone.	14.98295495947814
We gave our best blood to France and Spain, the wild geese.	8.745838833297103
Fontenoy, eh?	7.673417198419805
And Sarsfield and O’Donnell, duke of Tetuan in Spain, and Ulysses Browne of Camus that was fieldmarshal to Maria Teresa.	8.23900757042603
But what did we ever get for it?	10.177534788495885
—The French! says the citizen.	8.141972700642022
Set of dancing masters! Do you know what it is?	10.499922230998886
They were never worth a roasted fart to Ireland.	8.348107677323302
Aren’t they trying to make an _Entente cordiale_ now at Tay Pay’s dinnerparty with perfidious Albion?	11.789349572099061
Firebrands of Europe and they always were.	10.500775302605993
—_Conspuez les Français_, says Lenehan, nobbling his beer.	8.608869784270645
—And as for the Prooshians and the Hanoverians, says Joe, haven’t we had enough of those sausageeating bastards on the throne from George the elector down to the German lad and the flatulent old bitch that’s dead?	13.189704824352258
Jesus, I had to laugh at the way he came out with that about the old one with the winkers on her, blind drunk in her royal palace every night of God, old Vic, with her jorum of mountain dew and her coachman carting her up body and bones to roll into bed and she pulling him by the whiskers and singing him old bits of songs about _Ehren on the Rhine_ and come where the boose is cheaper.	11.42287383168366
—Well, says J.	7.9018106396258405
We have Edward the peacemaker now.	6.456469641010642
—Tell that to a fool, says the citizen.	7.656347341196942
There’s a bloody sight more pox than pax about that boyo.	10.646767821830105
Edward Guelph-Wettin! —And what do you think, says Joe, of the holy boys, the priests and bishops of Ireland doing up his room in Maynooth in His Satanic Majesty’s racing colours and sticking up pictures of all the horses his jockeys rode.	10.417401882918274
The earl of Dublin, no less.	12.922486838051542
—They ought to have stuck up all the women he rode himself, says little Alf.	12.602912092091598
And says J.	7.153864067816663
J.: —Considerations of space influenced their lordships’ decision.	10.818162830726356
—Will you try another, citizen?	14.221559329512345
says Joe.	5.2831441776690555
—Yes, sir, says he.	7.304294647626988
—You?	24.422391396819812
says Joe.	5.2831441776690555
—Beholden to you, Joe, says I.	6.787685760777926
May your shadow never grow less.	7.565930834833781
—Repeat that dose, says Joe.	4.692728884691557
Bloom was talking and talking with John Wyse and he quite excited with his dunducketymudcoloured mug on him and his old plumeyes rolling about.	9.851658404610466
—Persecution, says he, all the history of the world is full of it.	8.525830859682193
Perpetuating national hatred among nations.	8.842102523371231
—But do you know what a nation means?	21.097260624942734
says John Wyse.	7.903156667425854
—Yes, says Bloom.	7.865959450242127
—What is it?	8.031263818381309
says John Wyse.	7.903156667425854
—A nation?	32.13459290699695
says Bloom.	5.242049790701048
A nation is the same people living in the same place.	13.403304647707952
—By God, then, says Ned, laughing, if that’s so I’m a nation for I’m living in the same place for the past five years.	13.6045477995438
So of course everyone had the laugh at Bloom and says he, trying to muck out of it: —Or also living in different places.	13.216407144924808
—That covers my case, says Joe.	8.557757270116362
—What is your nation if I may ask?	17.454559263440117
—Ireland, says Bloom.	7.8270702032708375
I was born here.	12.918115212945697
Ireland.	13.682684331782813
The citizen said nothing only cleared the spit out of his gullet and, gob, he spat a Red bank oyster out of him right in the corner.	10.930440444660812
—After you with the push, Joe, says he, taking out his handkerchief to swab himself dry.	10.29513184034562
—Here you are, citizen, says Joe.	7.034888526880347
Take that in your right hand and repeat after me the following words.	11.290973112514267
The muchtreasured and intricately embroidered ancient Irish facecloth attributed to Solomon of Droma and Manus Tomaltach og MacDonogh, authors of the Book of Ballymote, was then carefully produced and called forth prolonged admiration.	6.434721614677739
No need to dwell on the legendary beauty of the cornerpieces, the acme of art, wherein one can distinctly discern each of the four evangelists in turn presenting to each of the four masters his evangelical symbol, a bogoak sceptre, a North American puma (a far nobler king of beasts than the British article, be it said in passing), a Kerry calf and a golden eagle from Carrantuohill.	10.703637250671289
The scenes depicted on the emunctory field, showing our ancient duns and raths and cromlechs and grianauns and seats of learning and maledictive stones, are as wonderfully beautiful and the pigments as delicate as when the Sligo illuminators gave free rein to their artistic fantasy long long ago in the time of the Barmecides.	7.994906462129469
Patrick’s Purgatory, the Salmon Leap, Maynooth college refectory, Curley’s hole, the three birthplaces of the first duke of Wellington, the rock of Cashel, the bog of Allen, the Henry Street Warehouse, Fingal’s Cave—all these moving scenes are still there for us today rendered more beautiful still by the waters of sorrow which have passed over them and by the rich incrustations of time.	10.607466883043768
—Show us over the drink, says I.	8.616656339439803
Which is which?	14.093234408100013
—That’s mine, says Joe, as the devil said to the dead policeman.	15.73621384217261
Also now.	4.779330306107821
This very moment.	7.999159759143073
This very instant.	10.336586229192989
Gob, he near burnt his fingers with the butt of his old cigar.	16.566651171038952
—Robbed, says he.	4.9348039687820355
Plundered.	32.172570290454246
Insulted.	32.172570290454246
Persecuted.	32.172570290454246
Taking what belongs to us by right.	6.540589017570099
At this very moment, says he, putting up his fist, sold by auction in Morocco like slaves or cattle.	9.090352273601345
—Are you talking about the new Jerusalem?	21.82164149913126
—I’m talking about injustice, says Bloom.	9.55593002884239
—Right, says John Wyse.	9.409917285112835
Stand up to it then with force like men.	9.770573984279983
That’s an almanac picture for you.	6.798631016388817
Mark for a softnosed bullet.	16.580722764639606
Old lardyface standing up to the business end of a gun.	13.535192848343765
Gob, he’d adorn a sweepingbrush, so he would, if he only had a nurse’s apron on him.	10.54484708555768
And then he collapses all of a sudden, twisting around all the opposite, as limp as a wet rag.	14.317869114514973
—But it’s no use, says he.	8.883990244810917
Force, hatred, history, all that.	5.076498082890719
That’s not life for men and women, insult and hatred.	10.36076285252678
And everybody knows that it’s the very opposite of that that is really life.	10.572203195943244
—What?	12.016783147492532
says Alf.	6.556971014434095
—Love, says Bloom.	7.419875300658261
I mean the opposite of hatred.	9.68995733820728
I must go now, says he to John Wyse.	11.441917290985165
Just round to the court a moment to see if Martin is there.	10.808265981559884
If he comes just say I’ll be back in a second.	14.013605661044064
Just a moment.	8.612295484836384
Who’s hindering you?	14.334200184092207
And off he pops like greased lightning.	7.444208477536578
—A new apostle to the gentiles, says the citizen.	9.090617932239404
Universal love.	7.552503918852979
—Well, says John Wyse.	10.290797413459176
Isn’t that what we’re told.	14.505422303642634
Love your neighbour.	10.385745597744803

Beggar my neighbour is his motto.	11.366014325645514
Love, moya! He’s a nice pattern of a Romeo and Juliet.	12.950906856362893
Love loves to love love.	7.224298948876225
Nurse loves the new chemist.	13.88210543558623
Gerty MacDowell loves the boy that has the bicycle.	11.950594394801668
loves a fair gentleman.	11.816418660695664
Li Chi Han lovey up kissy Cha Pu Chow.	5.604480580677621
Jumbo, the elephant, loves Alice, the elephant.	14.351868659876741
Old Mr Verschoyle with the ear trumpet loves old Mrs Verschoyle with the turnedin eye.	8.960699706501872
The man in the brown macintosh loves a lady who is dead.	12.903308342707598
His Majesty the King loves Her Majesty the Queen.	9.435888250959545
Mrs Norman W.	5.569497406875205
Tupper loves officer Taylor.	7.707549668873446
You love a certain person.	11.653748922047612
And this person loves that other person because everybody loves somebody but God loves everybody.	8.143561194567834
—Well, Joe, says I, your very good health and song.	10.194290341710385
More power, citizen.	6.541060492645177
—Hurrah, there, says Joe.	6.218084809390397
—The blessing of God and Mary and Patrick on you, says the citizen.	7.870742268741379
And he ups with his pint to wet his whistle.	12.539136958486477
—We know those canters, says he, preaching and picking your pocket.	7.749858451768733
What about sanctimonious Cromwell and his ironsides that put the women and children of Drogheda to the sword with the bible text _God is love_ pasted round the mouth of his cannon?	11.716426941478373
The bible! Did you read that skit in the _United Irishman_ today about that Zulu chief that’s visiting England?	11.993271270614313
—What’s that?	8.007760855344218
says Joe.	5.2831441776690555
So the citizen takes up one of his paraphernalia papers and he starts reading out: —A delegation of the chief cotton magnates of Manchester was presented yesterday to His Majesty the Alaki of Abeakuta by Gold Stick in Waiting, Lord Walkup of Walkup on Eggs, to tender to His Majesty the heartfelt thanks of British traders for the facilities afforded them in his dominions.	9.108977748908519
The delegation partook of luncheon at the conclusion of which the dusky potentate, in the course of a happy speech, freely translated by the British chaplain, the reverend Ananias Praisegod Barebones, tendered his best thanks to Massa Walkup and emphasised the cordial relations existing between Abeakuta and the British empire, stating that he treasured as one of his dearest possessions an illuminated bible, the volume of the word of God and the secret of England’s greatness, graciously presented to him by the white chief woman, the great squaw Victoria, with a personal dedication from the august hand of the Royal Donor.	10.863170327821848
The Alaki then drank a lovingcup of firstshot usquebaugh to the toast _Black and White_ from the skull of his immediate predecessor in the dynasty Kakachakachak, surnamed Forty Warts, after which he visited the chief factory of Cottonopolis and signed his mark in the visitors’ book, subsequently executing a charming old Abeakutic wardance, in the course of which he swallowed several knives and forks, amid hilarious applause from the girl hands.	8.123477178998657
—Widow woman, says Ned.	10.176320785675864
I wouldn’t doubt her.	8.442947776189035
Wonder did he put that bible to the same use as I would.	15.03418729115764
—Same only more so, says Lenehan.	8.598099587326386
And thereafter in that fruitful land the broadleaved mango flourished exceedingly.	7.281306127405601

Goodbye Ireland I’m going to Gort.	13.964370348935553
So I just went round the back of the yard to pumpship and begob (hundred shillings to five) while I was letting off my _(Throwaway_ twenty to) letting off my load gob says I to myself I knew he was uneasy in his (two pints off of Joe and one in Slattery’s off) in his mind to get off the mark to (hundred shillings is five quid) and when they were in the (dark horse) pisser Burke was telling me card party and letting on the child was sick (gob, must have done about a gallon) flabbyarse of a wife speaking down the tube _she’s better_ or _she’s_ (ow!) all a plan so he could vamoose with the pool if he won or (Jesus, full up I was) trading without a licence (ow!) Ireland my nation says he (hoik! phthook!) never be up to those bloody (there’s the last of it) Jerusalem (ah!) cuckoos.	10.532048535158799
So anyhow when I got back they were at it dingdong, John Wyse saying it was Bloom gave the ideas for Sinn Fein to Griffith to put in his paper all kinds of jerrymandering, packed juries and swindling the taxes off of the government and appointing consuls all over the world to walk about selling Irish industries.	9.103554291408713
Robbing Peter to pay Paul.	10.945465237162832
Gob, that puts the bloody kybosh on it if old sloppy eyes is mucking up the show.	11.40385942323935

Mr Bloom with his argol bargol.	18.260660167887178

No security.	15.009292486789496
